excerpts: Would definitely recommend the green onion pancakes, Xiao Long Baos, and the dry fried chicken.
The shanghai pan fried noodles were below average.
Overall, if you came here for the dry fried chicken, just stick to san tungs.
green onion pancakes.author: Charles S.
green onion pancakes.review: Just like what most other reviewers said, the service is horrible. We waited 1 hour for the dry fried chicken wings, the lady who waited on us had no expression on her face, and she was on her phone when we tried to flag her down. The food on the other hand was pretty good. Would definitely recommend the green onion pancakes, Xiao Long Baos, and the dry fried chicken. The shanghai pan fried noodles were below average. Overall, if you came here for the dry fried chicken, just stick to san tungs.

excerpts:
- Green Onion Pancakes : Not too oily and has a nice crunch and flavor to it
- Pan Fried Buns
(Sheng Jian Bao)
[pictured] :
Definitely one of my favorite dishes.
The presentation, taste, and texture is ON POINT.
It's like a 2.0 version of the shanghai dumplings.
However, it can sometimes be a bit oily
but that's what makes it good.
-Shanghai
Cu Chow Mein
(Stir-Fry) :
This dish is my favorite noodle dish by far.
green onion pancakes.author: Rachel C.
green onion pancakes.review:
Overall Rating: 3.5/5 

Food: 4/5 
After going to several Shanghai restaurants, this location serves the best shanghai restaurants. I would highly recommend 
- Shanghai Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) : The skin is nice and thin while the meat inside is juicy and flavorful
- Green Onion Pancakes : Not too oily and has a nice crunch and flavor to it
- Pan Fried Buns (Sheng Jian Bao) [pictured] : Definitely one of my favorite dishes. The presentation, taste, and texture is ON POINT. It's like a 2.0 version of the shanghai dumplings. However, it can sometimes be a bit oily but that's what makes it good. 
-Shanghai Cu Chow Mein (Stir-Fry) : This dish is my favorite noodle dish by far. Nice flavor and love the thick noodles.

Service: 2/5
Since they mainly have one waitress, the service is really slow. It usually takes 40 minutes until the food begins to arrive. There also isn't much space and somewhat cramped since the restaurant is really small. 

Overall, the food is great and affordable but the service and wait is often terrible.

excerpts:
Highlights include:
- Green onion pancakes: great texture and not too greasy
- Shanghai dumplings: honestly some of the best dumplings I've ever had - so juicy!
green onion pancakes.author: Regina L.
green onion pancakes.review:
Don't get me wrong, the food at Shanghai House is exceptional and I do feel bad giving a three star review, but everything else about the experience is mediocre at best. 

Let's start with the positives: arrived on a Friday evening around 7 with four friends and got sat immediately. We ordered a ton of food and EVERYTHING was fantastic. Service was pretty quick and the server was pretty responsive. Highlights include:
- Green onion pancakes: great texture and not too greasy
- Shanghai dumplings: honestly some of the best dumplings I've ever had - so juicy!
- Dry fried chicken wings: fantastic sauce, wanted to put it on everything else
- Mu-shu pork: great dish to share
- Hand cut noodles: my favorite dish - incredible noodles!

The not-so-great:
- We realized that we were given two completely different menus, so make sure that you get both menus to ensure you're seeing all of your options
- Cash only! Normally not a problem when I'm just picking up something for myself but for a large group it's a bit of a hassle
- Staff relatively unfriendly/aloof
- State of dining area could certainly use some upgrades/deep cleaning. Don't even get me STARTED on the state of their bathroom.
- Pretty far out there in the Richmond; it's definitely a trek to get over there from the other side of town

All in all, super glad I got to experience their food, but there are a ton of good places in the Chinatown area that would hit the spot and save me a ton of travel time.

excerpts: They served amazing dumplings (pan fried and soup) and green onion pancakes were delicious!
CASH
ONLY!!!
green onion pancakes.author: Rebeca K.
green onion pancakes.review: I'm visiting from Dallas and had a crave for good Chinese food. They served amazing dumplings (pan fried and soup) and green onion pancakes were delicious! CASH ONLY!!!

excerpts: Add green onion pancakes to your appetizer list too, your stomach will thank me later.
green onion pancakes.author: Chinsin S.
green onion pancakes.review:
The dumplings are always good. The soup inside is always served super hot and the whole thing usually melts in your mouth. Get a tray of 10 or 20, you won't regret it!

The chicken wings are amazing, so don't skip out on them. I haven't had San Tung's version yet, but this dish is delicious. Add green onion pancakes to your appetizer list too, your stomach will thank me later. Those are bomb-good!

This place isn't too expensive, so check it out if you're in the area. I'm taking a star off because the service is slow and the waiter--who is usually nice to my friend--is not too friendly to most customers. She needs to smile more.

excerpts: The green onion pancakes, vegetarian steamed dumplings, and vegetarian chow mein.
green onion pancakes.author: Pina U.
green onion pancakes.review:
One day after work - as I was hungry and craving Chinese food, I thought to venture over to this place... The one woman... She was extremely RUDE! ((It takes a lot to upset me.)) I received no acknowledgement upon entering the restaurant. Still, I walked up to her and kindly asked for a menu. I conveyed that I was ordering for "HERE". She seemed rushed. Anyhow I sat myself down after ordering three items. By the way, she did not offer water or tea to me - though I wasn't worried as I happened to have a full bottle of water with me. Though it was slightly bothersome to watch her bring food to people who had entered the restaurant much AFTER me. I waited... Waited... Also, it was so hard to flag her down to inquire re: the status of my order - as she made no eye contact with me and rushed to/from the back. 

Anyway, 45+ minutes later - she brought out my order via packed containers in a plastic bag... WHAT?! Again I reported I had ordered for "HERE" - and this time she replied with something along the lines of "I thought you ordered to go". She did NOT apologize for the misunderstanding. Note - when I'm hungry, I get irritated... Internally, I was so frustrated! Anyway, as I just wanted to get out of there (!!!), I paid (no tip as unbeknown to me, it ended up being to go), grabbed the food, and left (w/o getting soy sauce). 

I'm giving one star as the food was edible... The green onion pancakes, vegetarian steamed dumplings, and vegetarian chow mein. 

I wish I went elsewhere... Sadly, this place has horrible service... 

As one of the other reviews mentioned, I wish I spoke Chinese. Note, I was the only Indian person in the restaurant at the time. Perhaps the woman thought I was a lost tourist?

excerpts: Ordered 4 things to go today, pan fried Shanghai dumplings, pork dumplings, green onion pancakes and Shanghai noodles.
Went in and 4:15 or so.
There was a couple people eating in and 1 person ahead that ordered to go right before us.
There was 1 lady taking orders.
She was not very friendly.
No smile, very to the point.
Ok, I'm used to that at Chinese restaurants....
We didn't have cash
so my husband drove all the way to wells at the beach and back still no food
, it was 4:30.
The person who ordered togo before us just got her food.
Waited and waited, 4:55 hits she started packing some food up in a bag.
Thought that was ours, ready to pay, lady says "2 chicken wings?
We said "no".
She's said "ok not ready yet".
WTF!
At this point the restaurant was almost full.
We see people who sat way after us get their food...
"hmm
" we thought.
My husband (and I) were getting frustrated esp the lady not acknowledging us at all and how long we have waited.
We said ok 5 more minutes if we don't get anything we are leaving.
5 mins later still nothing
so I go to her and say "how much longer?
We've been here for almost an hour
" she says "pan fried shang hai dumplings take a long time".
So she goes to the back and asks where it is, she comes out with it, basiclaly immediately, and starts taking a couple dishes out of the previously packed to go order and hands it to us.
Hmmm
so she packed our food mistakenly in another order?!
She didn't apologize for the wait or anything (not sure why I even expected it).
Already annoyed, while driving home, my husband thought how much we paid and thought it was overpriced.
I checked the menu and recalculated and per my own calc after tax should have been $33 at most, we paid $36 and change!
Add to our frustration.
Got home and took the food out, the dumplings were packed in those compostable to go containers that when wet/moist, will warp.
They put these dumplings right on top with no wax paper or anything so the bottom of the dumplings got stuck to the container.
We basically had to rip off the bottom of each dumpling and if it did come off, we still needed to take the bottom off because there would be paper from the container stuck on the bottom.
Smh!
As for the noodles, the texture was too soft, all the ingredients kind of just mixed together like a pile of mush with tons of cabbage on top.
The green onion pancake was not layered like what we r used to, it was doughy.
As for the pan fried dumplings those were the best of the bunch but sadly still mediocre.
Safe to say we will not be back.
Usually if food is good, it can make up for horrible customer service (sometimes) but in this case, not even close, granted I know to-go can be vastly different vs when eaten fresh at the restaurant.
In this case I just don't think eating there would have made a difference.
Customer service: 0 stars.
Food: 0 stars

excerpts:
Green onion pancakes were very good, but no hot mustard to dip them in ("they were out.")
Combo fried rice had a weird flavor.
green onion pancakes.author: Adam G.
green onion pancakes.review:
dumplings a bit over-cooked such that skin soft and watery.
Wonton soup not great. The meat in the wontons seemed to be "mystery meat."
Green onion pancakes were very good, but no hot mustard to dip them in ("they were out.")
Combo fried rice had a weird flavor.

Lot's of better Chinese restaurants around. I don't understand why this one is generally very busy with Gringos who come from other areas of SF just for this restaurant.

excerpts: Green Onion Pancakes -- thin and slightly crunchy pancake, great with hot sauce.
green onion pancakes.author: Elaine N.
green onion pancakes.review:
My friend suggested Shanghai House because I had a craving for Shanghai Dumplings. This place did not disappoint. 

Shanghai Dumplings (XLB) -- lots of soup and meat, great balance of warm soup and gingered vinegar dipping sauce.

Green Onion Pancakes -- thin and slightly crunchy pancake, great with hot sauce. 

Pork&Veggie Potstickers -- savory pork, moist dumpling skin fried to crunchy perfection.

Shanghai Noodles -- udon sized noodles stir fried with veggies. Good but not my favorite.

excerpts: We ordered the Shanghai Dumplings, fried chicken wings, spicy noodles, and green onion pancakes from what I remember.
All were great choices, delicious, but not enough for the party of 5 (but didn't want to order more because overpriced for it's portions).
I ended up having to go next door to buy a sandwich.
Surprisingly, located next to my favorite smoked salmon sandwich cafe (La Promenade).
Popular for the Shanghai dumplings
aka Xiao Long bao
, I think the quality of it was average.
green onion pancakes.author: Mandy G.
green onion pancakes.review:
I couldn't decide between 2 stars or 3 stars; and don't know where to start! Lets start with the lines and work our way in.. 

First off, the food is good, overpriced, the service is poop, and the place is small with little walking space. This place is recommended for parties of 2-4, 5 max! If the restaurant is full, the first group will have to stand outside and wait in line. Though, there is no designated area to wait. If you're standing outside with your group, it looks like you're loitering. We came during dinner, just in time to beat the crowd. From what I witnessed by the windows, it was cold out. The second group of people that came in ended up coming into the restaurant to wait in the walkway and it seemed like they were also trying to cut the big group of people outside. 

My party of 5 was seated next to the door. For our table that seats 4, my cousin had to sit on the side where the walkway of the door is. The customers at the restaurant would be rude and pull the door in, hitting him instead of pushing. The restaurant should have a push/pull sign so customers know what to do without hitting others who are dining. When we first came, there were 2 tables often. The one next to the doorway and the table next to that one. We wanted the one inside because we knew someone had to be seated in the walkway, but she put us by the doorway which was very inconvenient. There seemed to only be 1 waitress and she was rude. She would see us waving her down then disappear into the back for a few mins. Come back out and talk to other customers who came in. Took us 5-10 mins to wave her down for the check and we were close to dine and dashing because it took so long. Took her 5 mins to come take our orders as well. 

 As for the food, it was delicious. My party and I did something similar to family-style, but it was little food for the 5 of us, I think. We ordered the Shanghai Dumplings, fried chicken wings, spicy noodles, and green onion pancakes from what I remember. All were great choices, delicious, but not enough for the party of 5 (but didn't want to order more because overpriced for it's portions). I ended up having to go next door to buy a sandwich. Surprisingly, located next to my favorite smoked salmon sandwich cafe (La Promenade). Popular for the Shanghai dumplings aka Xiao Long bao, I think the quality of it was average. Did not taste any different to other ones I've had. 

For the portion size, I felt that the food was overpriced. Service was crap, but food was good. Not worth it, and wouldn't recommend coming back here unless there is no wait and you want to spend your money on small portion sized food but good. Haha.

excerpts: The Green Onion Pancakes and the Green Beans with Veggies and Tofu dishes were just average.
It's not like they're easy to mess up anyways.
green onion pancakes.author: Jing D.
green onion pancakes.review:
There's a word called 'consistency' and Shanghai House doth not has it. 

I've been here now on several occasions, and up until my visit yesterday, my overall verdict is that SH is enjoyable and a good alternative to Shanghai Dumpling King a few blocks down the street. I even brought my parents here from the South Bay, and the XLB was judged to be so tasty that we added to our order.

But yesterday... I don't know what happened. First off, zero greeting whatsoever by the only lady holding it down solo. She just tossed the menus on our table. I know it's a Chinese place so had no expectations of superior service, but really? Not even a 'hi'? Dislike. Also, the place was not busy whatsoever. There were 3 tables occupied. Yet she preferred to take hiding behind a huge indoor plant that's been conveniently placed on the cash register counter, thus blocking her from overseeing the dining floor. It was difficult to get her attention when we wanted our check, and I could see behind the plant she was wolfing down a bowl of soup or something.

Moving on..The XLB was the real disappointment, however. They were tiny and flat instead of round and plumpy. It was almost an art to peel off the baos without tearing the bottom off of the steamer that's only been lined with parchment paper. Plus the ones that did succeed in landing in my soup spoon in one piece had such little juice, it almost didn't matter how meticulously you removed the baos.

The Green Onion Pancakes and the Green Beans with Veggies and Tofu dishes were just average. It's not like they're easy to mess up anyways. Tofu Seafood Soup was just okay too. 

This was really a 2-star experience. Added one star due to nostalgia of good past experiences. Get your act together! But for now, I'm going to Shanghai Dumpling King going forward.

excerpts:
Green onion pancakes: decent 

Meatball pot: had 4 big meatballs but very bland.
green onion pancakes.author: L Q.
green onion pancakes.review:
Came here for my sisters birthday. The place is pretty small-about 8 tables max. Service was so-so. There was a couple that sat down after us but there order was taken before ours-the lady taking the order made eye contact with me, knowing that we were ready. We ordered 5 dishes:

Shanghai pan fried noodles: no taste. Very bland

Green onion pancakes: decent 

Meatball pot: had 4 big meatballs but very bland. Looked better than it tasted.

Chicken wings: passable, but definitely had better.

Xiao long bao: best dish here. 

One thing I noticed and didn't like: the waitress took bowls from our table , didn't even bother to wash/wipe them and put them back on the dish rack. Even though we didn't use the bowls, it would have been nice to see her at least wiping them. Probably going to put them on other tables. 

Would I come back? Probably not. I rather go to the other shanghai place up the block.

excerpts: green onion pancakes pan fried thin, dense and dry....

dried fried chicken battered extra thick and oversized, but spicy candy sweet tangy garlic saucing similar to korean wings...too much batter...dan dan noodles straying from the standard and shanghai house creating own version...having more items, but too full...
dinner was just okay...
green onion pancakes.author: Hen A.
green onion pancakes.review: saturday dinner in the outer richmond...dinner for four and hungry!...requesting beers, but none...told to go next door to buy and bring back...six pack of modelo negro for $ten from the market...ready to order at shanghai house...xiao lung baos first...decent taste in filling...finding the wrapping little doughy and chewy...green onion pancakes pan fried thin, dense and dry....dried fried chicken battered extra thick and oversized, but spicy candy sweet tangy garlic saucing similar to korean wings...too much batter...dan dan noodles straying from the standard and shanghai house creating own version...having more items, but too full...dinner was just okay...

excerpts: To accompany it I ordered a couple more of my favorites, savory soy milk (available only on weekends) and green onion pancakes (available daily).
The green onion pancakes (cong you bing) made it three for three.
green onion pancakes.author: GarySoup I.
green onion pancakes.review:
When I hear about a new place that purports to be Shanghainese, I've got to check it out as soon as the opportunity arises.  When my SIL wanted to meet me for lunch and asked me for suggestions, it gave me an early opportunity to check out the newly opened Shanghai House (Jia JIa Fu) restaurant on Balboa with a couple of representatives from my Shanghai contingent in tow.

There was no doubt about Shanghai House's truly Shanghainese identity, with the server, the other parties there at early lunchtime, and two-thirds of my own party speaking Shanghainese (and me with my usual Yangjingbang). The menu, too, was rock-ribbed Shanghainese cuisine in its offerings, even if some of the "rice" dishes turned out to be somewhat eccentric home-style renditions. Unfortunately, some of the Shanghai "dim sum" items are only offered on weekends (which isn't made clear in the menu).

We ordered xiaolong bao; one cold dish (salted duck); a couple of "rice" dishes, Shanghai classic "meicai kourou" (steamed pork belly with pickled vegetables) and a tofu and seafood clay pot; and one soup, also a Shanghai classic, fried tofu with bean thread noodles.

I was able to approach the xiaolong bao with freshly calibrated taste receptors, having returned from Shanghai just two days before, and am happy to report that they were very good. Only an artlessness in the wrapping (they looked slightly misshapen) and a slight lack of flavor depth in the broth kept them from being the equal of Shanghai Dumpling King's and Oakland's Shanghai Xiao Chi's versions, but at $4.95 for 10 I'm willing to cut them a little slack. I made do with worse at several venues in Shanghai. They also made me vow to return on the weekend to try some of the other Shanghainese brunch items.

The other dishes were a mixed bag. The salty duck was tasty and lean, but had the appearance of being either too old or suffering from refrigerator burn, showing some discoloration and dryness. The pork belly/mei cai was marred by a too-sweet red sauce, but otherwise good. The tofu and seafood hot pot had fried tofu instead of the expected fresh tofu, and also suffered from a confusion of too many ingredients in it. It was almost as if all the ingredients one might toss into seafood hot-pot in the course of a leisurely hot pot dinner were crammed into a modest clay pot. This is not to say that there was anything leftover-ish about the contents; most of the ingredients appeared to be fresh and cooked just the right amount. If you are a seafood nut, this is the Chinese Cioppino for you.

The xifen/you doufu soup was the most peculiar of all. It came with an opaque brown broth, though neither I nor the two Shanghainese have ever seen this soup before with anything but a clear broth. It was savory enough, but a bit jarring visually.

I went return ed the following Saturday for lunch, intending to try some of the Shanghainese brunchie stuff only available on weekends. Nonetheless, I couldn't resist another shot at the xiaolong bao. To accompany it I ordered a couple more of my favorites, savory soy milk (available only on weekends) and green onion pancakes (available daily).

If anything, the xiaolong bao tasted even better than on my initial visit, probably because I brought more of a hunger with me, and were prettier, wrapped more carefully.

The savory soy milk (yan doujiang) turne about to be as good as I've had in SF since the early days of Fountain Court, better than Shanghai Dumpling King's version (good in its own right). It was properly sassy, and properly constructed, down to the inclusion of brine shrimp, which are often omitted. (Do they think those teeny little eyes are going to scare anybody?)

The green onion pancakes (cong you bing) made it three for three. I alsway cross my fingers when ordering this, because there are so many approaches to making it and with many different results, but Shanghai House's version was much to my liking: thick, well-browned and crunchy on the outside and soft and well-seeded with spring onion tops inside.

I talked to the server, who happened to be the daughter of the proprietor. Although she spoke English like an ABC, she had no problem understanding my little Shanghainese. She confirmed that it was a family operation, and said that it was dad who did all the cooking. The other server may have been the mom.

I'll reserve judgement on the regular lunch and dinner fare; our limited sampling of cold apps and rice dishes on our first visit found them to be a hit and miss proposition. But thanks to today's "hat trick" (sorry for that, but the Hockey Haven bar is only three doors up the street from SH) I have a new go-to place for Shanghainese eye-openers. 

[Update 11/10/07] - I downgraded my rating from 5 stars to a still-generous 4 because I finally got there for dinner.  I had my "Gang of Four" (Shanghainese inlaws in tow) and we found the main dishes to be eccentric and overly sweet, even for Shanghainese cuisine.

excerpts: I ordered green onion pancakes, wonton soup and pork dumplings.
green onion pancakes.author: Lina P.
green onion pancakes.review:
I stopped here after reading the newspaper article posted in the window, the title caught my attention: "Shanghai House is worth the wait," and so I waited. 

I ordered green onion pancakes, wonton soup and pork dumplings. I really enjoyed the pancakes and the soup, while the dumpling skin was a bit too thick for me. 

The service was a bit slow, but the wait gave me opportunity to observe other customers, which was nice.

I would definitely recommend the place to my friends and come back for the things recommended by other Yelpers that I didn't get a chance to try yet.

excerpts:
Green Onion Pancakes
Xiao Lung bao
green onion pancakes.author: Regi K.
green onion pancakes.review:
Green Onion Pancakes
Xiao Lung bao
soy been drink 
jelly fish salad
pickled vegetable and pork noodle soup
dry fried chicken wings
dry fried green beans
and most importantly, their salt and pepper pig knuckles....

yum, yum, good.....   

there are limited tables, and service is not really great.   
We go there early as we have a toddler who loves noodles.  

good place, just be sure to bring cash.

excerpts: We ordered the chow mien, shanghai dumplings, green onion pancakes and one hot sweet soy bean milk.
Green onion pancakes:
green onion pancakes.author: Jessica T.
green onion pancakes.review:
My boyfriend and I were hungry and found parking right in front. So we decided to try it out. We saw two parties sitting already so we walked in.

The waitress wasnt around so we sat ourselves. When she finally appeared she tossed the menus on the table. Let me say that it was NOT busy. So I don't know why she gave attitude...

Fast forward 20 minutes later, we were ready to order and the waitress was no where to be found again. When she came out of hiding we tried to flag her down 4 times before she slowly wobbled over to take our order at the exact same time my boyfriend got up to check on the meter. 

We ordered the chow mien, shanghai dumplings, green onion pancakes and one hot sweet soy bean milk. 

Chow mien: filled with hard cabbage and drenched in oil. Did I mention all you can taste is oil. Gross.

Hot sweet soy milk: it comes in a cup, with soy skin still in it. I don't think they freshly make it themselves since before stirring the glass it tasted likable water.

Shanghai dumplings: had better elsewhere. Half way into the meal the lady brings the vinegar. Thanks lady. The skins to thick for my liking.

Green onion pancakes: two small circles cut into pieces.

For me, nothing here was good. I'd rather drive another 30 minutes to new mandarin garden in south city.

excerpts:
Green onion pancakes
3)

Shanghai rice cakes with pickles and shredded porks
4) Spicy beef tendons
5)

Wonton and vegetable noodle soup
6)
green onion pancakes.author: Roserrele W.
green onion pancakes.review:
Hubby's friend suggested this restaurant to us and we tried it with the kids hoping to find a new place for our girl's birthday party. Parking was not easy as there was a concert 2 blocks away in Gold Gate Park.

We have ordered the following items for 5 people, 3 adults and 2 kids: -
1) Shanghai dumplings (siu lung bao) 10 small pieces
2) Green onion pancakes
3) Shanghai rice cakes with pickles and shredded porks
4) Spicy beef tendons
5) Wonton and vegetable noodle soup
6) Sweet soy milk

Overall, the food were tasty but portions were small as compared to Shanghai Dumping King a few blocks away. The kids loved soy milk the most and $1.65 for a big glass of kids-approved was really worth for us. The spicy beef tendons were quite hot and the cucumber was a good side of the dish. One thing that I really like is the ginger in the vinegar dipping sauce was cut thin enough and was plentiful to come with the shanghai dumplings.

Total amount of $36 including tax was a good deal and we have finished all the food.

The food would worth a 4-4.5 stars but at least 1 star has been deducted because of the service. The waitress has major attitude problem. She did not give us the menu (I went to take it myself) and kept ignoring us even when we tried to get the bill. I would rather go to Shanghai Dumpling King for my girl's birthday again. At least, we got pretty good services there all the times. For a restaurant, food is important but service should not be ignored. My hubby's friend said that the waitress always acts like that. When you go back several times and she recognizes you, her service would be totally different. Well, if you don't treat new customers good, how would they come back as returned customers? Fair enough?

excerpts:
Green Onion Pancakes 
3)

Vegetarian Fan Tuan (sorry, I don't know the English for this) 
4)

Veggie Goose 
5)
Veggie Dumplings (these are OK....not amazing...

but still) 
6)

Sweet Soy Milk 
7)
green onion pancakes.author: Lillian S.
green onion pancakes.review:
This place is AMAZING. It never disappoints. I visit the Shanghai House at least once a month since I'll start missing it. As a Buddhist vegetarian, I dislike onions and garlic in my Chinese food (AND DUH...lots of Chinese food is seasoned with this), and the waitress-owner lady is always very accommodating and makes sure that my food is prepared the correct way. This is what I always get: 

1) Winter Melon Soup (veggie broth) 
2) Green Onion Pancakes 
3) Vegetarian Fan Tuan (sorry, I don't know the English for this) 
4) Veggie Goose 
5) Veggie Dumplings (these are OK....not amazing...but still) 
6) Sweet Soy Milk 
7) Vegetable of the day sauteed. 

yeh...I eat a lot.

excerpts: Ofcourse we had the Shanghai Dumps, Pork & Shrimp Dumps, Veggie Dumps, Spicy Eggplant (excellent), Dry Fried Chix (excellent), Salt Pepper Pork Ribs (aah- dry), Green Onion Pancakes (yum), Hand cut noodles (Chow Fun).
All was good and tasty, the food came hella fast, we chowed down and were very satisfied.
It was very fulfilling, we were all stuffed.

Gotta try it for yourself!
G'
green onion pancakes.author: gordon g.
green onion pancakes.review:
My fam took me here last weekend and we had a great time.  The service was prompt, we made reservations in advance and walked right in to our table which was already set for four.
The menu was pretty large so we started to order many dishes.  Ofcourse we had the Shanghai Dumps, Pork & Shrimp Dumps, Veggie Dumps, Spicy Eggplant (excellent), Dry Fried Chix (excellent), Salt Pepper Pork Ribs (aah- dry), Green Onion Pancakes (yum), Hand cut noodles (Chow Fun).  All was good and tasty, the food came hella fast, we chowed down and were very satisfied.  It was very fulfilling, we were all stuffed.  Gotta try it for yourself!
G'

excerpts: The green onion pancakes were delicious and the hand cut noodles were a treat.
green onion pancakes.author: Josua P.
green onion pancakes.review:
Have you ever eaten so much Chinese food that you wonder if Chinese people ever say to themselves, "Man, Chinese food AGAIN?" Well recently I had the pleasure of eating with Ed M. and let me tell you, the answer is no. That dude loooves Chinese food. 

Shanghai house is in a tiny, somewhat sterile place in the hot spot of the Outer Richmond. If you consider the two block strip of Balboa that is home to just about every kind of  Asian cuisine and the Balboa Theater a hot spot. Actually, I think the only reason he chose this place was because he knew I had a car and that I LOVE to drive...'cause this place is in the sticks.

We got there and I just let him order. I figured he knew what the deal was AND he could speak Chinese. Very impressive. It was like a date except he didn't pull my chair out for me when I sat...that's why he only got to second base. Oh, and the wife and kid were there. COCK BLOCKERS! The food was really nice and as I am unfamiliar with Shanghai cuisine I found it was a nice departure from typical fried, greasy, heavy sauced Chinese food. Although there's a time and place for that shit too sometimes. The green onion pancakes were delicious and the hand cut noodles were a treat.

The main reason I'd come back is for the Shanghai dumplings. Their skin was light with a flavorful filling and were SUPER juicy. It was like there was a party in my mouth and everybody was coming. What? Why are you snickering? Oh, grow up, you guys. Really.

So basically, get yourself a Chinese friend who loves to eat and preferably speaks the language, let him roll you out to one his favorite spots and come hungry. And seriously, grow up.

excerpts: The 4 of us ordered a bunch of food including XLB (has juice inside!), green onion pancakes, soy milk w/ chinese donut, a few cold dishes and a few other dishes that I dont quite remember.
Anyway, the food here was pretty good and the service was excellent.
green onion pancakes.author: M W.
green onion pancakes.review:
Im not sure when Shanghai House opened, but when I went there 2 weeks ago everything was super clean as if it were all brand new. Restaurant is pretty small and superly QUIET. The 4 of us ordered a bunch of food including XLB (has juice inside!), green onion pancakes, soy milk w/ chinese donut, a few cold dishes and a few other dishes that I dont quite remember. Anyway, the food here was pretty good and the service was excellent. I shall be back.

note* 100pts on score card

excerpts: I also liked the Green Onion Pancakes (light and moist) and the Mu Shu Pork (one person disagreed, saying they taste burnt, but I loved that the cabbage still had some crunch in it).
Service was perfunctory at first but the woman running the floor warmed up as we went: I got a beautiful smile when I asked for a to go menu.
She even folded it for me :-)
green onion pancakes.author: Karsten P.
green onion pancakes.review:
The Tea Smoked Duck with dumplings is really, REALLY good. I was close to saying the hell with family style, I got mines -- but I restrained myself just enough to make it look like I wasn't getting the lion's share. The skin was just a bit crisp and the meat was tender and perfectly done, with a subtle smoky flavor that combined really well with the dumplings' hint of sweetness.

I also liked the Green Onion Pancakes (light and moist) and the Mu Shu Pork (one person disagreed, saying they taste burnt, but I loved that the cabbage still had some crunch in it). Service was perfunctory at first but the woman running the floor warmed up as we went: I got a beautiful smile when I asked for a to go menu. She even folded it for me :-)

excerpts: This small establishment serves a variety of traditional Shanghai-ness dishes - from green onion pancakes, shao lung bao and dumplings to dun dahn mein and drunken chicken.
All the ten plus dishes we had today were good, but nothing was spectacular and service was mediocre.
The great thing about this place is that the food isn't overly greasy.
My favorites from today were the green onion pancakes (very light and crispy) and drunken chicken (doused in alky...
green onion pancakes.author: Teresa Y.
green onion pancakes.review:
Today my family and I came here for lunch after my youngest sister's high school graduation. Lots of parking and there was a BOFA at the corner. There were about three handful of places to eat at in this neighborhood ten years ago. Since then, lots of new places have popped up.... Shanghai House being one of them. There is even a "People love us on Yelp!" sticker on the window.

This small establishment serves a variety of traditional Shanghai-ness dishes - from green onion pancakes, shao lung bao and dumplings to dun dahn mein and drunken chicken. All the ten plus dishes we had today were good, but nothing was spectacular and service was mediocre. The great thing about this place is that the food isn't overly greasy. My favorites from today were the green onion pancakes (very light and crispy) and drunken chicken (doused in alky... YUM!). 

Since this place is usually packed and there's quite the wait, I recommend coming here on a week night or Saturday lunch after 1pm.

excerpts:
Green Onion Pancakes - pretty good, no complaints
Hand Cut Noodles - very interesting

... cooked Shanghainese style with tons and tons of veggies
Little Sweet and Sour Ribs - just like I imagined... thick, dark, and sweet!
I kind of wish the rib pieces were bigger tho... it takes a lot of chewing around bones to get to the meat!
Lion's Head Meatballs - wow, so good!
green onion pancakes.author: Andrey C.
green onion pancakes.review:
I think Shanghai House is my new favorite place for xiao long bao! The bf and I had been hankering for xiao long bao for a while now, after being not-so-pleased by the ones we got at Taiwan Restaurant in Berkeley (oh my gosh... they were like the thick-skinned ones you can grab at dim-sum-to-go places!), we had been on the prowl for real xiao long bao, and this place came up.

So a few of our friends went last Friday night, happy to take up one of the last remaining tables of four. The lone waitress was kept pretty busy with the full house, but was still friendly and knowledgeable. Here's what we got:

Xiao Long Bao - A MUST EAT!! they're so tiny and precious, yet still delicious and juicy as they should be!
Green Onion Pancakes - pretty good, no complaints
Hand Cut Noodles - very interesting... cooked Shanghainese style with tons and tons of veggies
Little Sweet and Sour Ribs - just like I imagined... thick, dark, and sweet! I kind of wish the rib pieces were bigger tho... it takes a lot of chewing around bones to get to the meat!
Lion's Head Meatballs - wow, so good! the meatballs were really tender and tasty, with lots of veggies and huge mushrooms in a tasty sauce... great with rice!

One thing to note is that they do have two separate menus... one with the Shanghainese specialties and one with the standard Americanized "Chinese" fare, so be sure to look for the real deal. All in all, very happy with this discovery and will definitely come back!

excerpts:
(dao(1) xioa (1) mian(4)) = CRACK
Green onion pancakes (cong(1) you(2)
bing(3))
green onion pancakes.author: Cathy H.
green onion pancakes.review:
Deep fried fish filet (gan(1) pen(1) yu(2)) = ULTRA CRACK
Soup dumplings (xiao(3) long(2) bao(1)) = SHANGHAI DUMPLING KING MINUS THE GREASE AND MINUS THE MSG OVERDOSE
Homemade knife cut noodles (dao(1) xioa (1) mian(4)) = CRACK
Green onion pancakes (cong(1) you(2) bing(3)) = DECENT CRACK

Okay, it's not really crack, but better and purer. Coke ok?

Since they are just blocks apart, the cleanliness of Shanghai House over Shanghai Dumpling King makes this place my coke dealer of choice.

excerpts: The Green Onion Pancakes were really thick
- I prefer the thinner crispier kind
but they were pretty good.
green onion pancakes.author: Pamela L.
green onion pancakes.review:
The Xiao Long Bao is excellent. I debated whether to stick the first one in my mouth whole, because I didn't know how how the insides were going to be (it's soupy inside), but was pleasantly surprised (and grateful) that the soup was hot but not too hot - it was the perfect temperature. The skins were maybe a bit doughy, but it was still good.

The Green Onion Pancakes were really thick - I prefer the thinner crispier kind but they were pretty good. We really liked the beef brisket noodle soup and plan to try other noodle dishes next time.

The restaurant does kind of have a weird odor inside and the lady is kind of a grump. She speaks Cantonese but I think she'd rather not speak it if she doesn't have to (sticking to Mandarin/Shanghainese). She seemed to warm up after a bit though. Also, we got our dishes one at time so service was indeed kind of slow....

excerpts: The green onion pancakes are a MUST.
i could seriously chow down a whole order on my own.
My other favorites are the xiao long bao (dumplings,) beef brisket noodle soup, and chow nian gao! so good.
green onion pancakes.author: Kimberly K.
green onion pancakes.review:
i love this place for so many reasons, most of which will probably not apply to most of the people reading this (i.e. it's close to my house and i've been away at college where they do NOT have anything close to this kind of food.) 

The green onion pancakes are a MUST. i could seriously chow down a whole order on my own. My other favorites are the xiao long bao (dumplings,) beef brisket noodle soup, and chow nian gao! so good. just thinking about it makes me hungry... 

if you're in the neighborhood, check it out! The wait might be a litle more than desired, but it's mos def worth it!

excerpts: I get the Green Onion Pancakes, the pan-fried pork dumplings, the Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai Soup Dumplings)
and then usually I'll ask the owner to recommend something new.
Today we had a wonton purse soup which was good, but needed soy sauce.
Soup dumplings are hard to find, so I always get those.
At shanghai Restaurant they have a thicker wrapper, and sometimes the soupiness is inconsistent, but whatever, they're $6.
And delicious.
green onion pancakes.author: Selin K.
green onion pancakes.review: I really like Shanghai Restaurant. Its a hole in the wall kind of place, right in the hustle and bustle of Oakland's Chinatown. Everything here is solid. Its no Yank Sing, but thats ok- Its also 1/3 the price! I get the Green Onion Pancakes, the pan-fried pork dumplings, the Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai Soup Dumplings) and then usually I'll ask the owner to recommend something new.  Today we had a wonton purse soup which was good, but needed soy sauce. Soup dumplings are hard to find, so I always get those. At shanghai Restaurant they have a thicker wrapper, and sometimes the soupiness is inconsistent, but whatever, they're $6. And delicious.

excerpts: The other dishes were forgettable: flat stir-fried noodles with beef and vegetable, green onion pancakes, spicy braised tofu, and honey walnut prawns, while not the best in their respective classes, were actually good value relative to the prices.
green onion pancakes.author: Ange L.
green onion pancakes.review:
Shanghai House was a solid 2-star until the bill came... and after realizing that $8 per person (including tip) got our plump selves squared and good to go, I decided to add one additional star.  

This unassuming Chinese (or should I say, Shanghainese) establishment was tucked away in the far end of Richmond, away from the hustle and bustle of Clement Street (where, quite possibly, 90% of Inner Richmond Chinese restaurants are located).  As a result, parking situation is a tad better, and as we found out, prices are a lot lower.  

The wait... was still expected.  But then again, we had a large group and it was prime dinner time, so a 40-min wait was not horrendously out of line.  

As always, we had to try the pork Xiao Long Bao and compare it with the other legendary XLBs: Din Tai Fung and Joe's Shanghai.  While neither of these places could beat the price - 10 for $5.25 - I wasn't too impressed by the small, doughy variety with much-less-than-expected amount of soup in those little packets.  

The other dishes were forgettable: flat stir-fried noodles with beef and vegetable, green onion pancakes, spicy braised tofu, and honey walnut prawns, while not the best in their respective classes, were actually good value relative to the prices.

excerpts: our usual order: dumplings (2 orders), five spice beef, green onion pancakes (varies, but usually tip top), vegetarian goose (pressed tofu skin) stuffed with mushrooms, chinese style sweet/sour pork - read:
Chinese style, not the orange goop, special noodle (knife cut - their speciality).
i usually roll out the door and into the car.
a walk around the block (okay, several blocks), I am ready for another dumpling run.
Run, do not walk there.
You won't be sorry!
green onion pancakes.author: Sonia C.
green onion pancakes.review: Outrageous "shiu long boa", or little dragon dumplings.  scary good.  our usual order: dumplings (2 orders), five spice beef, green onion pancakes (varies, but usually tip top), vegetarian goose (pressed tofu skin) stuffed with mushrooms, chinese style sweet/sour pork - read: Chinese style, not the orange goop, special noodle (knife cut - their speciality).  i usually roll out the door and into the car.  a walk around the block (okay, several blocks), I am ready for another dumpling run.  Run, do not walk there.  You won't be sorry!

excerpts: The hand cut noodles and rice cake were great as well as the green onion pancakes.
I would definitely go back because the food was good and well priced.
Small place so expect to wait.
green onion pancakes.author: goldberg d.
green onion pancakes.review: I give this place 3.5 stars.  The xiao long bao where good however not the best I've had in San Francisco.  I actually reserve that for Yank Sing in the Rincon center.  The skin was a little to thick and not sturdy enough which may sound weird.  The amount of broth and flavor was right on.  The hand cut noodles and rice cake were great as well as the green onion pancakes.  I would definitely go back because the food was good and well priced.  Small place so expect to wait.

excerpts: Yummy xiao long baos and green onion pancakes.
Simply deelish, especially after the experience I had at Spices II the same afternoon.
I really like the look of the place too.
It was clean and didn't look like a tacky Chinese restaurant.
The service was alright, nothing to complain about.
I will definitely come back to try the other items.
They look so yummy!
green onion pancakes.author: Audrey T.
green onion pancakes.review: Yummy xiao long baos and green onion pancakes. Simply deelish, especially after the experience I had at Spices II the same afternoon. I really like the look of the place too. It was clean and didn't look like a tacky Chinese restaurant. The service was alright, nothing to complain about. I will definitely come back to try the other items. They look so yummy!

excerpts: We ordered the Shanghai dumplings,  green onion pancakes, pork/noodle soup,  and the dry fried wings.
Total approx $25.
The dumplings were not the best that I have had, but very good.
The noodles in the soup were hand cut(not hand pulled) and perfectly chewy.
The dry fried wings were perfect. as good as So's.
green onion pancakes.author: T L.
green onion pancakes.review:
Eating at good ethnic/Chinese restaurants makes me wonder why I pay $5 and up for a sandwich or $10 for a plate of pasta. The amount of effort that goes into making a good bowl of noodle soup or plate of dumplings makes me feel guilty that I am paying them so little.

Anyway, Shanghai house as the other yelpers have pointed out is way out there in the 30th ave and Balboa area. There is not much else in the area except for a movie theater and some other ethnic eateries. But  I would definitely make out a trip out here again just for a meal.

The restaurant is small, clean and fairly new. We ordered the Shanghai dumplings,  green onion pancakes, pork/noodle soup,  and the dry fried wings. Total approx $25. The dumplings were not the best that I have had, but very good. The noodles in the soup were hand cut(not hand pulled) and perfectly chewy. The dry fried wings were perfect. as good as So's. better than the wings at OB town in Oakland.  

Food *****
Value *****
Decor **

excerpts: green onion pancakes were okay, a little on the salty side.
make sure you call first too see if they have any more dumplings left.
green onion pancakes.author: Jen C.
green onion pancakes.review:
so annoyed.  i went here specifically to try their shanghai dumplings, and they didn't have anymore wtf!!! and this was at lunch time.  i don't get it, maybe all the local highschoolers ate them all.

green onion pancakes were okay, a little on the salty side.
make sure you call first too see if they have any more dumplings left.

excerpts: Green onion pancakes were soggy and oily.
I'm not going back....
green onion pancakes.author: Tommy B.
green onion pancakes.review: Waaay overrated. Had some shanghai dumplings that were so dry, I didn't even finish it. For anyone who knows shanghai food, their dumplings are supposed to be filled with soup. Green onion pancakes were soggy and oily. I'm not going back....

excerpts: Other delicious dishes that are my favorite: pot stickers, soy beans (edamame) with bean curd noodles & pickled mustard greens, green onion pancakes, Shanghai noodles, braised noodles with green onion and dry shrimp, and malted dry chicken wings.
This place is small, but the service is attentive and quite clean.
Cheap but cash only.
green onion pancakes.author: Cindy K.
green onion pancakes.review: They serve the best pork dumplings (xiao long bao) in the Bay Area. (Haven't found any that is better) Other delicious dishes that are my favorite: pot stickers, soy beans (edamame) with bean curd noodles & pickled mustard greens, green onion pancakes, Shanghai noodles, braised noodles with green onion and dry shrimp, and malted dry chicken wings. This place is small, but the service is attentive and quite clean. Cheap but cash only.

excerpts: The green onion pancakes were dry and doughie - really subpar.
green onion pancakes.author: Silvia L.
green onion pancakes.review:
I was so irritated by this place that I decided to sign up to Yelp and write about it.

First, the food ain't all that.  The only reason we decided to have lunch there was because Dumpling King was closed for vacation.  The xiao long bao was not juicy and whatever juice that was there was lost since the skin was so fragile and ripped as we tried to pick them up.  We tried the chicken wings since everyone else there was having them too.  The skin was yummy but the meat itself had no taste.  The green onion pancakes were dry and doughie - really subpar.

Now for the irritating part... We patiently waited for a table for about 30 minutes.  Once we sat down, we thought, great, food is coming up!!  Well, it took 15 more minutes for us to get some tea!!!!  Another 15 min for the 1st dish to come out, another 15 minutes for the 2nd and so on... we were there for 2 HOURS!!   I had the urge to leave the restaurant 3 different times.  There was a period of more than 15 minutes that the kitchen didn't come out with A SINGLE dish to ANY table...  

I'll never go back.  EVER.

excerpts: So from start to finish, we had the green onion pancakes, dry fried chicken wings, pork and preserved green hand cut noodle soup, lion's head meatballs (not really a lion's head people), XLB, and soy bean milk.
I'm pretty sure I'm missing something since I counted 7 things on the check
but for the life of me can't remember.
Everything we had was delicious - my favorites being the lion's head meat ball, hand cut noodle soup (mostly because of the noodles -
I think I've had the beef noodle soup
and I think I liked it more), and the dry fried chicken wings.
Note: Everything else was good, just picking my favorites.
The chicken wings actually have a leg up on Santung and are spicier/crispier.
The only thing with the wings is that they are sweet, but I have a feeling if you like Santung you won't mind this one too.
Just working on watching the sugar + calories, so that made me a bit sad... had to restrain myself from eating the whole thing
so I wouldn't have a heart attack.
green onion pancakes.author: Jeannette L.
green onion pancakes.review: What surprises me about this place is that despite the fact that I thought we had over ordered, we somehow managed to finish everything. So from start to finish, we had the green onion pancakes, dry fried chicken wings, pork and preserved green hand cut noodle soup, lion's head meatballs (not really a lion's head people), XLB, and soy bean milk. I'm pretty sure I'm missing something since I counted 7 things on the check but for the life of me can't remember. Everything we had was delicious - my favorites being the lion's head meat ball, hand cut noodle soup (mostly because of the noodles - I think I've had the beef noodle soup and I think I liked it more), and the dry fried chicken wings. Note: Everything else was good, just picking my favorites. The chicken wings actually have a leg up on Santung and are spicier/crispier. The only thing with the wings is that they are sweet, but I have a feeling if you like Santung you won't mind this one too. Just working on watching the sugar + calories, so that made me a bit sad... had to restrain myself from eating the whole thing so I wouldn't have a heart attack.

excerpts: Here, however, there is a 'Meal for One' option that includes soup, and egg roll, rice or chow mien, and an entree.
egg roll.author: Eric M.
egg roll.review:
Shanghai house gets a good review for one major reason: they offer a decent Chinese meal for one person.  All too often, a single person going out for Chinese is stuck getting one big heaping serving of orange chicken or some similar dish that is best had with a big group, not all by one's lonesome.  Here, however, there is a 'Meal for One' option that includes soup, and egg roll, rice or chow mien, and an entree.

The food is really good, the service was fast and friendly, and the prices were very reasonable.

Overall, quite tasty.

excerpts: The potstickers were okay.
The dry pan fried garlic string beans were good.
The green onion pancake was too thick for my liking and too brown.
It wasn't burnt but it was getting there.
The chicken chow
potstickers.author: Michelle T.
potstickers.review:
From sitting down to getting the first dish we ordered was 1 hour. Needless to say, that's a ridiculous amount of time to wait. We placed our order about 10 minutes after we sat down. If this restaurant has more than 2 parties, I suggest you stay far away unless you have 1+ hours to spare. 

The food was mediocre and not memorable. The pan fried hand pulled noodle was lacking in flavor. The xiao long nap had no soup. The potstickers were okay. The dry pan fried garlic string beans were good. The green onion pancake was too thick for my liking and too brown. It wasn't burnt but it was getting there. The chicken chow  mein was okay. 

I ordered the fried chicken but they forgot to write down that order so I never got it. That's a bummer because the table near us got it and it looked good.

excerpts:
We ordered:

- Xiaolongbao (soup dumplings)
- Stir-Fried Shanghai Noodles
- Dry Chicken Wings
- Pan Fried Dumpling
- Pan Fried Potstickers

Food was delicious!
The Pan Fried Dumplings and the Pan Fried Potstickers had a nice crispy, yet chewy exterior.
Both of the fillings were tasty, as well.
Out of the three, my favorite was the Pan Fried Dumplings.
The Stir-Fried Shanghai Noodles were okay
, nothing really made it stand out though.
Lastly, the Dry Chicken Wings were excellent!
Some say it's comparable to San Tung's wings, but honestly they're incomparable.
It's not horrible, it's just different in looks and taste, so one cannot simply compare the two.
The wings here have a nice crunch to them with a sweet caramelized sugar glazing.
potstickers.author: Julia L.
potstickers.review:
The wait can be long and the service is the bare minimum, but the food is awesome!

This is my second time here and both times I've had good experiences. The first time around I remember I had to wait a bit to be seated, but this time my party and I got seated immediately. The same individual (I assume is the owner) took our orders. Both times, this individual did not show much emotions or expressions, she just took our orders, refilled our tea pot from time to time, and that was about it. Food was delivered directly by the chefs.

We ordered:

- Xiaolongbao (soup dumplings)
- Stir-Fried Shanghai Noodles
- Dry Chicken Wings
- Pan Fried Dumpling
- Pan Fried Potstickers

Food was delicious! The Xiaolongbao had a thin exterior that held the soup fairly well and had a juicy filling. The Pan Fried Dumplings and the Pan Fried Potstickers had a nice crispy, yet chewy exterior. Both of the fillings were tasty, as well. Out of the three, my favorite was the Pan Fried Dumplings. The Stir-Fried Shanghai Noodles were okay, nothing really made it stand out though. Lastly, the Dry Chicken Wings were excellent! Some say it's comparable to San Tung's wings, but honestly they're incomparable. It's not horrible, it's just different in looks and taste, so one cannot simply compare the two. The wings here have a nice crunch to them with a sweet caramelized sugar glazing. Not to mention, the size of the wings are generous.

Overall, a great Shanghainese restaurant on Balboa. Parking can be a hassle in the area and the service isn't particularly outstanding, but food definitely hits the spot!

PS: All photos were taken by the bf since I was too busy eating (he takes better photos than me anyway).

excerpts: BUT - I will say, their potstickers are pretty bomb.
Potstickers - 4 stars!
Noodle dish with meat
(Forgot what it was on the menu, lol, but it was near the Tan Tan noodles) - 3.5 stars - felt like the noodles were home-made - or just really fresh!
potstickers.author: Emily C.
potstickers.review:
Decent food (except the steamed dumpling!) but overall average experience.

I could see this as a popular local spot, but wouldn't come out of my way to return! BUT - I will say, their potstickers are pretty bomb. They are plump and the skin outside is not too doughy, and perfectly browned & crisped.

Service: Standard, for a typical Chinese restaurant. No smiles here!
Ambiance: Looks & feels like a hole in the wall spot.
Food: Overall about 3.5 stars. 

BREAKDOWN:
Dumplings - 2 stars. Too doughy and not enough filling.
Potstickers - 4 stars!
Noodle dish with meat (Forgot what it was on the menu, lol, but it was near the Tan Tan noodles) - 3.5 stars - felt like the noodles were home-made - or just really fresh! Silky and bouncy, and the sauce that accompanied it was pretty good too!

If I were to return, I'd like to try the chicken wings! The portions looked hefty and it looks like it's twice fried.. which means probably delicious.

excerpts:
We decided to order the Potstickers, Shanghai Dumplings, Dry Fried Chicken Wings, and Green Onion Pancake. 
All four of these dishes pertain to the basic dim sum meal, so we thought it would be a good idea to order these items. 
The potstickers weren't noticeably magnificent in taste, but they're still good!
The Shanghai Dumplings/Xiao Long Bao was great and definitely worth the order!
The chicken wings are probably close to San Tung quality and something worth checking out.
potstickers.author: Jeffy Y.
potstickers.review:
A great semi hole-in-the-wall dim sum place despite flaws in service!

1) First Impression
It was a Monday night around 7PM and there were many tables open. The lady quickly seated us and you can tell right away she's one of those grumpy old Chinese ladies. Nothing wrong with that though, but just saying. Also, this place is definitely quite small and I can imagine it being completely packed in here on perhaps a Friday night or weekend night.

2) Wait Time
My party of 3 did not have to wait on a Monday night around 7PM.

3) The Food
We decided to order the Potstickers, Shanghai Dumplings, Dry Fried Chicken Wings, and Green Onion Pancake. All four of these dishes pertain to the basic dim sum meal, so we thought it would be a good idea to order these items. 
The potstickers weren't noticeably magnificent in taste, but they're still good!
The Shanghai Dumplings/Xiao Long Bao was great and definitely worth the order!
The chicken wings are probably close to San Tung quality and something worth checking out.
The green onion pancake was also pretty crisp and is a great staple to have with the meal.

4) Service
The lady didn't smile a single time throughout the whole time we were there.
It seemed like she just wanted to get through the rest of the night and could care less about impeccable customer service. In addition, it took her about 20 minutes to give us our bill after we asked for it. However, this was OK because we were all having a nice conversation and wasn't in a rush to get out of the restaurant. To be honest, you shouldn't have high expectations on service if you're going to an authentic Chinese restaurant.

5) Pricing
The items are definitely leaning towards the pricey end of around $7-$11 per dish.
I don't know if the chicken wings are worth the ~$11 the menu advertises, but we were all full in the end and finished everything without any leftovers.

Keep in Mind: 
Parking may be harder to find, especially with Purple Kow across the street.
Speaking of Purple Kow, we went there right after dinner so it's a convenient location for some Dim Sum + Purple Kow combo.

*Final Verdict*
If you're looking for a good Dim Sum place and don't care too much about incredible customer service, then this is the place for you. I gave it 4 stars because the fair customer service really didn't bother me too much at that time.

excerpts: The 'dumplings' I ordered looked more like potstickers than a dumpling.
Disappointed with my meal, I asked the waitress if I could order the Shangahi house dumpling rather and have the incorrect dumplings taken back.
She looked at me and said 'no
no the cook already made the food, you can not have that taken back at all.'
So I was caught off guard and pissed at this point.
As soon as she walked behind me and at the kitchen, my partner saw her look at me with disgust and talked to her coworkers in mandarin.
I don't like to judge or assume, but she was more than likely talking about me in a negative term.
The waitress made our entire experience horrible.
potstickers.author: Michael T.
potstickers.review:
Went to this place after having it catered at my office during lunch. Thought that going to the actual restaurant would be a fun and exciting experience. Wrong. 

My partner and I were waited on right away and was given a seat without having to wait at all. Great. But service the moment we sat down, absolutely horrible. 

The waitress, which only seemed to be one, was absolutely rude, unkind, unprofessional, and down right unhappy. First, as other reviews stated, her apron didn't seem to be clean whatsoever and neither did the menus given to us to order our food. If you do not like having white people there, please state that, as she did not treat us with respect and had a merry ok time with other mandarin groups. I'm not one to be racist at all, but that is not right.  

This was my first time here and wanted to order dumplings, which I did, but ordered the wrong kind (I ordered veggie and pork dumplings when I later found out, once my food arrived, that I should have ordered the Shanghai house dumplings.) The 'dumplings' I ordered looked more like potstickers than a dumpling. Disappointed with my meal, I asked the waitress if I could order the Shangahi house dumpling rather and have the incorrect dumplings taken back. She looked at me and said 'no no the cook already made the food, you can not have that taken back at all.' So I was caught off guard and pissed at this point. As soon as she walked behind me and at the kitchen, my partner saw her look at me with disgust and talked to her coworkers in mandarin. I don't like to judge or assume, but she was more than likely talking about me in a negative term. The waitress made our entire experience horrible. Even having to pay was a nightmare. 

BRING CASH ONLY! We were not aware of this restaurant being cash only. There was no sign out front, nothing labeled on the menu, and certainly not told by the waitress before hand. We finished our meal and wanted to pay by credit card. Left it on the table as we predicted it would be a hassle to ask for the check. As we waited we finally flagged her down as she was not giving us the time of day otherwise. She approached our table, saw the credit card, picked it up and actually threw it back down on the table stating 'we do not take credit cards, only cash.' With a total disgust on her face. As we did not have any cash on us, I was forced to go to the ATM a block away and get cash for the bill (which isn't a big deal but wish I had known beforehand.) We were so unpleased with this experience. 

On a better note, and the reason I gave it a two star rather than a 1, is because the food was good considering everything else that happened. Nothing was wrong with our food, we ate everything we had ordered, and nothing was cold. That's all this place has to offer is the food, which is a given, but was really hoping it would have great service and a more welcoming environment.

excerpts: The XLB were passible, the hot beef on noodles were quite good, the potstickers were good.
The service was beyond atrocious.
potstickers.author: Paul T.
potstickers.review: The XLB were passible, the hot beef on noodles were quite good, the potstickers were good.  The service was beyond atrocious.

excerpts:
Potstickers - pork and veggies
Meh!
Average potstickers.
potstickers.author: Elena N.
potstickers.review:
I was craving Xiao long bao and Dry fried chicken wings. I've had Shanghai house bookmarked for some time, so instead of trekking across the park into the Sunset to get my fix, I thought I'd finally check Shanghai house off my list. I called in the take out order and the roommate picked it up about 30 mins later.

Dry chicken wings - chicken wings deep fried in batter with garlic, ginger and roast red peppers
A little sweeter than I prefer. The roommate said it was cuz they use honey instead of corn syrup. Though honey is probably better for you, I prefer a different sweetener as the honey overpowered the savory aspect of the dish.

Xiao long bao
These were delish! The skin held up well in the take out container. None of them burst so they all kept their juicy goodness. I liked the thickness of the wrapper and the consistency of the filling.

Potstickers - pork and veggies
Meh! Average potstickers. Nothing to write home about.

Dry sauteed string beans - fresh green beans flash fried and tossed in a garlicky sauce with Chinese pickle
These did not taste dry fried at all! Almost like blanched strings beans mixed in sauce. So bland! They got better the next day but then they got mushy.

House special eggplant - shrimp, chicken and fresh basil
The roommate's pick since he wanted something healthier. I actually liked this dish. Had great flavor and the eggplant was cooked nicely.

Combo fried rice
Burnt! The whole dish tasted burnt. I know sometimes a little smokiness can be good, but not in fried rice and not to this degree! The cook should have known not to serve this. I'm surprised they gave it to us to take home. Probably hoping we wouldn't complain which we didn't so I guess they scored there.

I might come back just for the Xiao long bao, but with Shanghai dumpling king just down the street with better offerings in terms additional dishes, I'll probably skip Shanghai house. No one should be serving burnt rice!

excerpts:
Potstickers - not worth. 
Puny doesn't even begin to describe them.
Chicken wings - never arrived! 
FAIL.
Spicy sliced beef - thin sliced beef and tendon tossed in spicy chili oil. 
Laid over a bed of sliced cucumbers that definitely help cut the spice - very yummy.
Stir fried rice cakes - nothing special, but also not bad.
Deep fried pork chop noodle - lots of noodle, but the deep fried pork chop was all bone - LAME.
potstickers.author: Elaine Y.
potstickers.review:
3.5 stars. Some dishes were excellent, others were really skimpy. 

1. XLB - Decent - skin was thin and soup was plenty, but the pork lacked flavor.
2. Potstickers - not worth. Puny doesn't even begin to describe them.
3. Chicken wings - never arrived! FAIL.
4. Spicy sliced beef - thin sliced beef and tendon tossed in spicy chili oil. Laid over a bed of sliced cucumbers that definitely help cut the spice - very yummy.
5. Stir fried rice cakes - nothing special, but also not bad.
6. Deep fried pork chop noodle - lots of noodle, but the deep fried pork chop was all bone - LAME.
7. Pickled veggie and salted pork rice - liked the crispy rice on the bottom, but it would have been better if the salted pork actually infused the rice - kind of plain.

and last but not least...

8. Salt and pepper pork knuckle - DEFINITE WINNER. Fork tender meat with a crispy exterior. Served over a bed of crispy kale chips. I could just eat this alone with endless bowls of rice. So yummy! Portion is more than enough for multiple meals, so don't balk at the $24 price tag.

Service was okay. The young gent definitely seemed overwhelmed at times. He would deliver a dish and astutely comment that we needed serving utensils or bowls or whatnot....but then never bring them. Awkward.

excerpts: We ordered fried chicken and the potstickers.
They were both delicious.
The fried chicken is crispy with the sticky sweet sauce.
The potstickers had perfect skin and the meat was juicy.
I will come back.
potstickers.author: Melissa C.
potstickers.review: Tiny restaurant, the tables and chairs were sticky to touch. But the food is great. We ordered fried chicken and the potstickers. They were both delicious. The fried chicken is crispy with the sticky sweet sauce. The potstickers had perfect skin and the meat was juicy. I will come back.

excerpts: Potstickers -- savory pork, moist dumpling skin fried to crunchy perfection.
potstickers.author: Elaine N.
potstickers.review:
My friend suggested Shanghai House because I had a craving for Shanghai Dumplings. This place did not disappoint. 

Shanghai Dumplings (XLB) -- lots of soup and meat, great balance of warm soup and gingered vinegar dipping sauce.

Green Onion Pancakes -- thin and slightly crunchy pancake, great with hot sauce. 

Pork&Veggie Potstickers -- savory pork, moist dumpling skin fried to crunchy perfection.

Shanghai Noodles -- udon sized noodles stir fried with veggies. Good but not my favorite.

excerpts: I waited for maybe 5 minutes, and took a seat and decided on the general Tsao chicken lunch special and a plate of potstickers.
The portions were large and in charge and everything had great flavor.
Great value for the price.
Cash only.
I will return....
potstickers.author: Andy S.
potstickers.review: I had a really nice, and honestly better than expected meal at Shanghai House recently.  My first visit was for a late, 2pm lunch on a weekday- and the place was jam-packed even at this time.  I waited for maybe 5 minutes, and took a seat and decided on the general Tsao chicken lunch special and a plate of potstickers.  The portions were large and in charge and everything had great flavor.  Great value for the price.  Cash only.  I will return....

excerpts:
we ordered Shanghai Dumplings (xiao long bao), Hand Cut noodle and Potstickers.

The Potstickers were average.
potstickers.author: Mei C.
potstickers.review:
Came here for lunch since we planned on going across the street to Purple Kow for drinks after wards.

Upon entering the restaurant, the female waitress/hostess was on her cell phone and ignored us. We stood there like idiots not sure if we were supposed to seat ourselves or to continue to wait. After what seems like an eternity (which is probably more like 5 minutes) with the already seated patrons looking at us... the chef (male worker) came out and noticed us. He motioned us to a table and started getting the attention the the female waitress to get off her phone. She looked irritated that he was telling her to get off her cellphone. 

Anyways... we ordered Shanghai Dumplings (xiao long bao), Hand Cut noodle and Potstickers.

The Shanghai Dumplings were ok. I prefer Shanghai Dumpling Kings a few blocks away more.

The Hand Cut Noodle was ok. Had a lot of cabbage and not enough noodle. 

The Potstickers were average.

They also accidentally gave us the vegetarian goose and when we pointed out that we did not order it... the lady kept asking us if we wanted to keep it. Which we did not want or we would've ordered it to begin with. At least she didn't charge us for it. 

All in all... I will not go back since Shanghai Dumpling King is only a few blocks away and taste much better and cheaper.

excerpts: Potstickers:
Husband's all 'Potstickers?
Really?'
I did it anyway, sorry dude, and Oh My God GET the potstickers!
They were wow!!
Small, delicious, perfectly pan fried morsels of goodness.
Tan Tan noodles:
Uhm, no.
Looked beautiful, taste...not so much.
But you know, anything we had after the potstickers was not gonna be that good.
Potstickers at Shanghai House with boba from Purple Kow for dessert.
Grin.
potstickers.author: El B.
potstickers.review:
Mayflower is gone, so I'm looking to fill the dim sum hole in my life.  Went here tonight. Ok, not really a dim sum place, BUT:

Pork and vegetable dumplings: good
XLB: Yay. No leakage, good flavor, I'm a fan.
Potstickers: Husband's all 'Potstickers? Really?' I did it anyway, sorry dude, and Oh My God GET the potstickers! They were wow!!  Small, delicious, perfectly pan fried morsels of goodness. 
Tan Tan noodles: Uhm, no.  Looked beautiful, taste...not so much. But you know, anything we had after the potstickers was not gonna be that good. 

Ok, not Mayflower. But I have a new potsticker place. 
Price? Ridiculously cheap.
Bonus: Purple Kow is across the street. Perfect meal? Potstickers at Shanghai House with boba from Purple Kow for dessert. Grin.

excerpts: Now, potstickers are probably the last thing I would order at a Chinese restaurant for fear of frozen/not-good sides.
However, the potstickers here were surprisingly delectable, with the right amount of crisp and a yummy inside.
Hand Cut Noodles were VERY good here.
potstickers.author: Tracy Joy K.
potstickers.review:
Shanghai House packs a whole lot of yummy into a tiny little place! I came here with my girlfriends on a day where we were basically eating up all of San Francisco. Even after a day of packing ourselves with food, we still had an appetite for this place! 

XLB was great here, I do like the ones from Kingdom of Dumpling better but these were a good start to our meal. Now, potstickers are probably the last thing I would order at a Chinese restaurant for fear of frozen/not-good sides. However, the potstickers here were surprisingly delectable, with the right amount of crisp and a yummy inside. Hand Cut Noodles were VERY good here. I am a big fan of Mandarin/Taiwanese style noodles and these were a great filler to the whole meal. 

Now the big question might be in question of their chicken and if it beats the almighty San Tung. Not having tried San Tung myself I am not sure, however this chicken did make me a believer. I'm usually not a big fan of fried chicken wings however the spicy, sweet, crispy goodness definitely converted me. I'll just have to try San Tung and put it to the test! Caution to the wings is that these are SPICY so be ready fill up on your tea and ask for some water. 

My group was actually lucky that we didn't have to wait. It does get a little awkward with people standing around waiting for a table, so try to come early to beat the traffic. 
I would definitely recommend this little place to anyone looking for good Chinese eats!

excerpts: we ordered some regular potstickers, soup, chicken, etc.
Then started the waiting game......after about 20 minutes we see the first dish we order come out...but they take it to a different table.
About 5 minutes later the waitress grabs it off of their table and puts it on ours.
Not cool to either of us.
The food trickles in on our table at an extremely odd pace.
potstickers.author: Daniel K.
potstickers.review:
We only came here because shanghai dumpling king was closed.  

Named Shanghai House we though we could easily get some Shanghai dumplings especially since it's the first item on the menu.  When we tried to order some the waitress told us not too because they didn't have any ready and it would take at least 30 minutes to get some.  Ok that sucks......but I guess we'll just order some other stuff....we ordered some regular potstickers, soup, chicken, etc.  Then started the waiting game......after about 20 minutes we see the first dish we order come out...but they take it to a different table.  About 5 minutes later the waitress grabs it off of their table and puts it on ours.  Not cool to either of us.  The food trickles in on our table at an extremely odd pace.  It pretty much ended up being something like...here is a dish, we finish it, here is another dish, rinse and repeat.

The real problem I had with the place is that I realized that we might as well have ordered the Shanghai dumplings since it pretty much took us 45 minutes to get all of our meal items and we saw other tables getting the dumplings.

excerpts: Potstickers are amazing and on that alone they get three stars...
potstickers.author: David H.
potstickers.review: Good and greasy authentic chow that comes with fair amount of sour attitude. Potstickers are amazing and on that alone they get three stars...

excerpts: Their potstickers and green onion pancake are average.
potstickers.author: Meredith K.
potstickers.review:
Gyeah, take me back here!  I'm not a shanghai dumpling aficionado but these dumplings are pretty damn good to me.  Also, you must order the fried chicken wings - almost as good as San Tung's.  The tan tan mein is good, spicy than other places I've had it.  Their potstickers and green onion pancake are average.  The rice cakes are pretty good and taste homemade.   

The two times I've been here I haven't had to wait for a table.  So if you want your San Tung of the Richmond - come here.  The service isn't 5 stars but the food makes up for it.

excerpts: Some dishes along the lines of a Shanghai rice cake, potstickers, xiao long bao, veggie dish, sweet buns for dessert.
potstickers.author: Vanna S.
potstickers.review:
Old classmates/friends gathering of four.  This was few months back and really the things we ordered did not really stood out.  Some dishes along the lines of a Shanghai rice cake, potstickers, xiao long bao, veggie dish, sweet buns for dessert.

I do remember that the service was ok, food was cheap, we were so damn stuffed.

excerpts: I also ordered potstickers.
Potstickers is one of those dishes that's so common
it's hard to imagine anything out of the ordinary.
If you think  potstickers are all made the same, I highly recommend trying Shanghai House's potstickers.
potstickers.author: matt c.
potstickers.review:
It's 3.5 stars but the cleanliness really pushes it up to 4 stars. 

Since its a Shanghai restaurant I ordered two simple dishes. 

1.) Xiao Lung Bao (Small Steamed Dumpling)
2.) Postickers

Xiao Lung Bao is very very delicate, a good Xiao Lung Bao is defined by its uber-thin skin, juicy meat inside, and just the right amount of weight to be picked up by chopsticks without juices flowing everywhere. 

Shanghai House's version is good but not perfect.  The skin is a little thick, not unbearable but a bit thick.  Juices a little thin and the bottom sticks a little bit.  What's important though this restaurant produces a very good authentic version of Xiao Lung Bao.  It's not perfect but very very good. 

I also ordered potstickers.  Potstickers is one of those dishes that's so common it's hard to imagine anything out of the ordinary.  If you think  potstickers are all made the same, I highly recommend trying Shanghai House's potstickers.   The filling is nice and juicy, the bottom is crispy, it's a delight to eat, I throughly enjoyed mine. 

They also have Chinese breakfast including Sweet and Salty rice balls, soy milk, fried dough etc.  I'm gonna try to head back on the weekends to try out their breakfast.

excerpts:
This is what I order with my girlfriend all the time here:
-Shanghai Dumplings (so very wet and juicy and good)
-Potstickers (also very juicy and good... makes me forget about AJ's open ended wrapped potstickers)
-Hand
Cut Noodles
(oh man soooo good

it makes me cry)
