-Savory rice wrapped hand roll with chinese donut (I don't know what it is called exactly because I always order this in mandarin...
but it is a fried chinese donut wrapped with pork sung and rice.

)
-Savory or Sweet Soy Milk!
potstickers.author: Benny S.
potstickers.review:
Shanghai House is my new favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco!

This is what I order with my girlfriend all the time here:
-Shanghai Dumplings (so very wet and juicy and good)
-Potstickers (also very juicy and good... makes me forget about AJ's open ended wrapped potstickers)
-Hand Cut Noodles (oh man soooo good it makes me cry)
-Savory rice wrapped hand roll with chinese donut (I don't know what it is called exactly because I always order this in mandarin... but it is a fried chinese donut wrapped with pork sung and rice.)
-Savory or Sweet Soy Milk!  They offer cold or hot for sweet soy milk!

This place can accomodate more than 6 people parties, but VERY hard.  So the perfect amount for this place is either 2-4 people.  The place also get get very packed so prepare to wait... but sometimes if you cannot wait there is a nice japanese restaurant called Miki right next door that is also just as awesome.

Parking is semi-tough... this place is right across one of the few independant theaters and boy do alot of people still go there.  Balboa theater probably is the main reason why all the parking is taken... #2 reason would be maybe Zephyr's Cafe.  I sometimes park a block up on Anza because of how packed it can get.

The only negative I can say about this place is the service.  As nice as the lady is to us now that we are here so often.. it still isn't the best service out there in a Chinese restaurant.  Suck it up and ignore the staff and enjoy one of San Francisco's best chinese spots!  This place is truely a hidden hole in the wall!

WARNING: This review is based on not trying the other dumpling place 2 - 3 blocks away also on Balboa.

excerpts: Their potstickers are the equivalent size of Mcdonald's chicken nuggets.
No joke.
The bulk of their food is pretty bland, and I found myself dousing quite a bit of soy sauce for more flavor.
Perhaps my biggest gripe has to be the owner/server there.
It's an old woman with this look on her face that makes you think she's going to kill someone.
Ok maybe a little harsh, but she seriously NEVER smiles.
Not even the slightest grin.
Ever.
potstickers.author: jeff c.
potstickers.review:
What is the deal with this place?  It's been buzzin amongst the Asian community for the past few months and hyped as THE premiere Shanghai restaurant in the city. All I have to say is you're going to be severely disappointed.

Today was my third visit to this place and as I sat there, I kept on wondering why I continue to come back. I think it's because I really do want to like this place, but they keep on coming up short. I'm a huge fan of Shanghai cuisine and have been looking  for a replacement for my fave Shanghai Restaurant, which closed down at Ranch 99 a few months ago.

My gripes. Someone needs to tell the chef to ease up on the flames.  All the noodle, rice cake, and chow fun orders I sampled were overcooked and mushy; all I tasted was dough. The portions are also  ridiculously small. Their potstickers are the equivalent size of Mcdonald's chicken nuggets. No joke. The bulk of their food is pretty bland, and I found myself dousing quite a bit of soy sauce for more flavor. Perhaps my biggest gripe has to be the owner/server there. It's an old woman with this look on her face that makes you think she's going to kill someone. Ok maybe a little harsh, but she seriously NEVER smiles. Not even the slightest grin. Ever. Go see for yourselves and tell me if I'm lying.

I'd say the only thing this place got going on for them is their Shanghai steam dumplings, or xiao long bao. Although a little on the small side, they're probably one of the best I've ever tasted. Immaculate skin texture and cooked to perfection. These lil suckers are probably the only reason I'll ever go back there and why they're getting 3 stars instead of 2.

excerpts: Potstickers -
Would like it if it was bigger in size.
Never seen potstickers this small before
but they sure look cute! =
potstickers.author: sidney c.
potstickers.review:
Came here on a Monday around 11:30am and the place was already full with one group of two waiting for a table before us.  There was only one waiter taking orders and one lady cleaning the table so everything from waiting for a table, ordering and getting the food took a while.  If you want to try this place be sure to have ample time waiting.  My boyfriend and I took approximately 30-45 minutes to eat only and we didn't get to leave until 2:30pm.  

As far as the food goes:

Dumplings (xiao lung baos) - Good..like the thin and soft skin to it. Not much soup  in the dumplings though.  Meat isn't as tasty as the ones in Old Shanghai restaraunt on Geary but overall I like it because of the thin skin.

Green onion pancake - A little too dry and hard but otherwise tastes the same as any other places I've tried.

Potstickers - Would like it if it was bigger in size.  Never seen potstickers this small before but they sure look cute! =P

Shanghai Stir Fry Noodles - Had better at Old Shanghai Restaurant on Geary.  This one didn't have enough flavors to it and the noodles are not as chewy as the ones on Geary.  

Place is clean and prices are rather cheap.  Maybe worth to wait for the dumplings only.

excerpts: Decent chinese food, nothing more to say about it; potstickers and chowmein.
Prices were cheap and service was efficient.
The one thing I do have to say is there extremely slow here!!
Came here once in the morning
and there was only one other table
and we waited 40 minutes for our food.
Maybe its there strategy to keep the place looking like it actually has customers.
potstickers.author: rwanda t.
potstickers.review: Decent chinese food, nothing more to say about it; potstickers and chowmein.  Prices were cheap and service was efficient. The one thing I do have to say is there extremely slow here!! Came here once in the morning and there was only one other table and we waited 40 minutes for our food. Maybe its there strategy to keep the place looking like it actually has customers.

excerpts: the onion waffles along with potstickers and rice made for one lunch that I would love to replay over and over again.
potstickers.author: Alvin P.
potstickers.review: JUICY PORK DUMPLINGS!!! man, these little pouches of deliciousness explode flavorful juices that you could only dream of. haha. all perversion and jokes aside, 3 orders of these badboys just wasn't enough. the onion waffles along with potstickers and rice made for one lunch that I would love to replay over and over again.

excerpts: Potstickers, not bad.
MIni-sized but packs a decent punch.
Tea soaked duck.
A little on the salty side and a lot of fat.
Boo...
Tan Tan Noodles.
Spicy.
Good.
Lots of oil.

Clogging...
Bean Curd Puff.
The review they had up had a picture of it and the plate did not look like the picture at all!
Deception!
But it was still good.
Although I could have made it myself at home.
Easy stuff.
Shanghai Noodles.
Bland.
Sweet Soy Bean Milk.
Hot.
Wanted to try the savory one because of the picture on yelp
but they didn't have it.
Whack!
Sweet one was whatever.
Chinese donut.
Doughy.

Eh...
Green Onion Pancake.
Also doughy.
potstickers.author: Jimmy N.
potstickers.review:
Not bad, not bad at all... But growing up with asian food, my expectations are quite high. And this place just made the cut.

The place was smaller than I had anticipated. Pretty clean and decently modern decor with some asian influence. 

Their oh-so-famous shanghai dumpling. Pretty good but not something I've never had before. It's comparable to Koi Palace's shanghai dumpling and only a little more than half the price of Koi's. Good stuff.
Potstickers, not bad. MIni-sized but packs a decent punch.
Tea soaked duck. A little on the salty side and a lot of fat. Boo...
Tan Tan Noodles. Spicy. Good. Lots of oil. Clogging...
Bean Curd Puff. The review they had up had a picture of it and the plate did not look like the picture at all! Deception! But it was still good. Although I could have made it myself at home. Easy stuff.
Shanghai Noodles. Bland.
Sweet Soy Bean Milk. Hot. Wanted to try the savory one because of the picture on yelp but they didn't have it. Whack! Sweet one was whatever.
Chinese donut. Doughy. Eh...
Green Onion Pancake. Also doughy. Should have listened Natalie L.'s advice.

Bathroom. Through the kitchen, up the stairs. Apparantly the stairs only leads to the bathroom and nothing else. Weird.

Good dinner though. Probably better for lunch.

excerpts: Great Xiao Long Baos and nice crispy potstickers and some goose wrapped in tofu skins.
what can be better? also ordered the shanghai fried noodles, but the dumplings were better dishes.

only downside is that it's a small place and gets a little crowded and and the friendly staff (of 2) is frantically running around refilling tea, getting checks, and dropping off more Xiao Long Baos at different tables.
This place reminds me very much of The Noodle Shop near Hillsdale Mall.
potstickers.author: Douglas F.
potstickers.review: Nothing tastes better than hot dumplings on a cold night in SF. Great Xiao Long Baos and nice crispy potstickers and some goose wrapped in tofu skins. what can be better? also ordered the shanghai fried noodles, but the dumplings were better dishes. only downside is that it's a small place and gets a little crowded and and the friendly staff (of 2) is frantically running around refilling tea, getting checks, and dropping off more Xiao Long Baos at different tables. This place reminds me very much of The Noodle Shop near Hillsdale Mall.

excerpts: the potstickers were...not good potstickers.
more like funny shaped shanghais, crispy on the bottom.
potstickers.author: Missniche W.
potstickers.review:
wow! yuuuuummmy! 
i couldn't give this place 5 stars and here's why- a tsingtao is always fantastic with a chinese meal and there is no liquor license. also, the single waitress for the restaurant was just not nice. i'm well aware of cultural differences, however service is service and she would not smile, was not attentive, paid  no heed to the order of dishes or amount of space available on the table for food. i also noticed it was not just my table (me being black and my cohorts being caucasian)- but she was equal opportunity cold, withdrawn and indifferent to every table- oh, and ps- there is no life or decoration at shanghai house. i think one plant. luckily my 5 companions were worthy of paying attention only to my immediate surroundings...and the food.

the food was phenomenal! the vegetarian goose ( i AM NOT a vegetarian- far from it!) was amazing. a light tofu and mushroom dish with unexpected delectable flavor. the dumplings were pretty good. not the best i ever had, but better than most. the potstickers were...not good potstickers. more like funny shaped shanghais, crispy on the bottom. the chinese eggplant, chicken and shrimp dish left me wanting more and the sesame chicken was perfectly crisp and saturated. the fish and shittake mushrooms (our best guess was some kind of bass) left my mouth humbled, thinking that i had had it better before. all in all, i will definitely go back and enjoy the food immensely.

i should mention that we brought a 6-pack of brew in and there's no corkage (screwage, whatever)- so if you like a cold beer with your chinese cuisine- do it!

and last but not least, the bill for 6 people who lurrve food and have no shame in saying "another one of those, please" was (drum roll please)...75 bones. yes, shanghai house...your cold and aloof waitress, room devoid of personality, spectacular food and more than accommodating prices have won me over...and i'll be back!

excerpts: Faves include potstickers, vegetarian goose, kung pao prawns and anything else we ever order.
This isnt the place to go for proper, timely service and they don't serve alcohol but you can bring your own!
I often bring my own wine and glasses!!
No Corkage fee... and again, the food rocks.
It's like cornstarch never existed and the only types of vegetables were fresh...
potstickers.author: let's c.
potstickers.review: This is the best Chinese food I have ever eaten. It is fresh and flavorful and the textures are bang on. If you want greasy, heavy Chinese, don't come here. I have brought many different people here and they always love it. Faves include potstickers, vegetarian goose, kung pao prawns and anything else we ever order. This isnt the place to go for proper, timely service and they don't serve alcohol but you can bring your own! I often bring my own wine and glasses!! No Corkage fee... and again, the food rocks. It's like cornstarch never existed and the only types of vegetables were fresh...

excerpts: Fried Tofu was really bland.
fried tofu.author: Helen S.
fried tofu.review:
Racists mofos.  My mom, boyfriend (who happens to be Haitian), and I came here to eat and it took FOREVER for us to get all our food.  My boyfriend's dish was the last to arrive and it wasn't even what he ordered!  He wanted to ADD broccoli to his dish and after waiting almost 30 min, when his dish arrived, they said it doesn't come the way he requested.  DUH!  Which is why he wanted to add it at an extra cost.

Being mandarin, I grew up on this type of food and it is definitely not as good as Shanghai Dumpling King.  The dumplings were ok and the "Chinese Donut" was too oily.  Fried Tofu was really bland.

Horrible service, ok food, metered parking even on holidays, and racists mofos.  NEVER AGAIN!

excerpts: The other items we ordered were okay,  a little too heavy on the oyster sauce on our stir-fry Buddha's Delight which has broccoli, fried tofu, bok choy and carrots.
fried tofu.author: Janice C.
fried tofu.review:
Brusque and slow service combined with ordinary food, I don't think I'll be back here anytime soon.   

You know I'm here for a reason and it's to check off an item on my Big Eat SF list:

#13 soup dumplings at Shanghai House. 

10 pieces of hot Xiao Long Bao brought out in a bamboo steamer.  The soft texture of the steamed wrapping paper, well-seasoned pork, and tasty soup in these one-bite dumplings make you thankful that these only cost $5.50.  (which would cost you $10 at Yank Sing)  

The other items we ordered were okay,  a little too heavy on the oyster sauce on our stir-fry Buddha's Delight which has broccoli, fried tofu, bok choy and carrots.   Our shrimp fried rice had a weird burnt taste although the shrimp itself was plump and tender.   The walnut prawns? a skip. 

This place is small but can probably accommodate around 30 people.  Be prepared to wait if they get busy.  

BTW, cash only.

excerpts: I also recommend the fried tofu.
We got here early before the lunch rush...
it is a small place
so be prepared to wait in busy times...but it will be well worth the wait
fried tofu.author: Chris H.
fried tofu.review: Excellent dim sum....I have had dumplings this good since I visited china.  I also recommend the fried tofu.  We got here early before the lunch rush...it is a small place so be prepared to wait in busy times...but it will be well worth the wait

excerpts: We ordered xiaolong bao; one cold dish (salted duck); a couple of "rice" dishes, Shanghai classic "meicai kourou" (steamed pork belly with pickled vegetables) and a tofu and seafood clay pot; and one soup, also a Shanghai classic, fried tofu with bean thread noodles.
The tofu and seafood hot pot had fried tofu instead of the expected fresh tofu, and also suffered from a confusion of too many ingredients in it.
It was almost as if all the ingredients one might toss into seafood hot-pot in the course of a leisurely hot pot dinner were crammed into a modest clay pot.
This is not to say that there was anything leftover-ish about the contents; most of the ingredients appeared to be fresh and cooked just the right amount.
fried tofu.author: GarySoup I.
fried tofu.review:
When I hear about a new place that purports to be Shanghainese, I've got to check it out as soon as the opportunity arises.  When my SIL wanted to meet me for lunch and asked me for suggestions, it gave me an early opportunity to check out the newly opened Shanghai House (Jia JIa Fu) restaurant on Balboa with a couple of representatives from my Shanghai contingent in tow.

There was no doubt about Shanghai House's truly Shanghainese identity, with the server, the other parties there at early lunchtime, and two-thirds of my own party speaking Shanghainese (and me with my usual Yangjingbang). The menu, too, was rock-ribbed Shanghainese cuisine in its offerings, even if some of the "rice" dishes turned out to be somewhat eccentric home-style renditions. Unfortunately, some of the Shanghai "dim sum" items are only offered on weekends (which isn't made clear in the menu).

We ordered xiaolong bao; one cold dish (salted duck); a couple of "rice" dishes, Shanghai classic "meicai kourou" (steamed pork belly with pickled vegetables) and a tofu and seafood clay pot; and one soup, also a Shanghai classic, fried tofu with bean thread noodles.

I was able to approach the xiaolong bao with freshly calibrated taste receptors, having returned from Shanghai just two days before, and am happy to report that they were very good. Only an artlessness in the wrapping (they looked slightly misshapen) and a slight lack of flavor depth in the broth kept them from being the equal of Shanghai Dumpling King's and Oakland's Shanghai Xiao Chi's versions, but at $4.95 for 10 I'm willing to cut them a little slack. I made do with worse at several venues in Shanghai. They also made me vow to return on the weekend to try some of the other Shanghainese brunch items.

The other dishes were a mixed bag. The salty duck was tasty and lean, but had the appearance of being either too old or suffering from refrigerator burn, showing some discoloration and dryness. The pork belly/mei cai was marred by a too-sweet red sauce, but otherwise good. The tofu and seafood hot pot had fried tofu instead of the expected fresh tofu, and also suffered from a confusion of too many ingredients in it. It was almost as if all the ingredients one might toss into seafood hot-pot in the course of a leisurely hot pot dinner were crammed into a modest clay pot. This is not to say that there was anything leftover-ish about the contents; most of the ingredients appeared to be fresh and cooked just the right amount. If you are a seafood nut, this is the Chinese Cioppino for you.

The xifen/you doufu soup was the most peculiar of all. It came with an opaque brown broth, though neither I nor the two Shanghainese have ever seen this soup before with anything but a clear broth. It was savory enough, but a bit jarring visually.

I went return ed the following Saturday for lunch, intending to try some of the Shanghainese brunchie stuff only available on weekends. Nonetheless, I couldn't resist another shot at the xiaolong bao. To accompany it I ordered a couple more of my favorites, savory soy milk (available only on weekends) and green onion pancakes (available daily).

If anything, the xiaolong bao tasted even better than on my initial visit, probably because I brought more of a hunger with me, and were prettier, wrapped more carefully.

The savory soy milk (yan doujiang) turne about to be as good as I've had in SF since the early days of Fountain Court, better than Shanghai Dumpling King's version (good in its own right). It was properly sassy, and properly constructed, down to the inclusion of brine shrimp, which are often omitted. (Do they think those teeny little eyes are going to scare anybody?)

The green onion pancakes (cong you bing) made it three for three. I alsway cross my fingers when ordering this, because there are so many approaches to making it and with many different results, but Shanghai House's version was much to my liking: thick, well-browned and crunchy on the outside and soft and well-seeded with spring onion tops inside.

I talked to the server, who happened to be the daughter of the proprietor. Although she spoke English like an ABC, she had no problem understanding my little Shanghainese. She confirmed that it was a family operation, and said that it was dad who did all the cooking. The other server may have been the mom.

I'll reserve judgement on the regular lunch and dinner fare; our limited sampling of cold apps and rice dishes on our first visit found them to be a hit and miss proposition. But thanks to today's "hat trick" (sorry for that, but the Hockey Haven bar is only three doors up the street from SH) I have a new go-to place for Shanghainese eye-openers. 

[Update 11/10/07] - I downgraded my rating from 5 stars to a still-generous 4 because I finally got there for dinner.  I had my "Gang of Four" (Shanghainese inlaws in tow) and we found the main dishes to be eccentric and overly sweet, even for Shanghainese cuisine.

excerpts: Following the soup I ordered Fried Tofu.
Very nice.
Was not deep fried like the other Fried Tofu's out there.
The fried skin is very thin - covering the tofu just barely.
The tofu was also soft - not firm which is the right way to make fried tofu.
This
fried tofu.author: Killah K.
fried tofu.review:
A quaint and cozy place that delivers relatively good food at reasonable prices. The owner and the Chef themselves are actually Shanghai-nese (I myself come from Shanghai, China) so that brought my expectations even higher. 

The first thing I ordered was the Shanghai pork dumplings. You can't come to a Shanghai-nese restaurant without first trying the dumplings. The dumplings were Good. Juices were flowing inside the skin and the skin itself was not hard - which tells you that they are using the right kind of skin. The meatball inside was also cooked perfectly. So for the dumplings, it has my vote. ::thumbs up:: 

I then ordered the Sour and spicy soup - which to my surprise was kind of disappointing. Way too sour for my taste and not spicy at all. Unbalanced and very one-sided. The amount of veggies included in the soup was pretty good, but I couldnt taste any of it due to the overwhelming sour-ness. There was also a slight bitterness that I didn't like. Maybe they derived from the traditional way of making this soup in order to make it more original? I do not know. 

Following the soup I ordered Fried Tofu. Very nice. Was not deep fried like the other Fried Tofu's out there. The fried skin is very thin - covering the tofu just barely. The tofu was also soft - not firm which is the right way to make fried tofu. This I give my ::thumbs up:: 

The Mongolian Beef and the Kung Pao Chicken was pretty good. The Kung Pao was definitely spicier than the Mongolian Beef however and the peanuts compliments it very very well. The Mongolian Beef was nice and tender, but I had preferred it to be just as spicy or spicier than the Kung Pao. 

Overall, the experience was a good one. The service was okay considering that there's only one waiter there. It would've been nice if they had accepted major credit cards, but I guess it is to keep costs low. A little inconvenient, but bearable. Bank of America is literally a block away on the corner. 


Bottom Line: More or less authentic with some deviation from traditional depending what you get. Overall good experience. It was good, but not fantastic. I do support local businesses so I would go here again.

excerpts: Zha Do Fu - Fried tofu appetizer
- this was OK - I mean.. what could go wrong.
Tasted like decently good store-bought tofu that had been fried.
Accompanying sauce was uninteresting.
The main event: xiao long bao - these were only OK - too sweet and the skin was dry and a little crumbly -
I've had better.
Main dish: Tofu Noodles with Edamame -
this tasted like nothing - funky-ass texture, disgusting presentation, and no flavor.
fried tofu.author: Austin L.
fried tofu.review:
This is my first one-star review... In an effort to maintain credibility I'm going to use the old tried and true Zagat framework to organize my thinking and response.

Decor:  When I first walked in I got a really weird feeling - the restaurant is a small, rectangular, beige-colored room with no decoration whatsoever.  Furthermore, there was no music on and oddly hushed conversation.  I felt like I had made a big mistake by even walking through the door.  Once we'd been seated the front door kept opening ON ITS OWN and letting the cold richmond air blow across my neck.  Not fun.


Food:  Started with a hot and sour soup - this was just plain bad.  I've had unremarkable H&S before but this was outright awful.  Extremely sour with no hot... lack of flavor, odd vegetables, disjointed, and simply wrong.  I had about 3 spoonfuls before putting it aside.  Zha Do Fu - Fried tofu appetizer - this was OK - I mean.. what could go wrong.  Tasted like decently good store-bought tofu that had been fried.  Accompanying sauce was uninteresting.  The main event: xiao long bao - these were only OK - too sweet and the skin was dry and a little crumbly - I've had better.  Main dish: Tofu Noodles with Edamame - this tasted like nothing - funky-ass texture, disgusting presentation, and no flavor.  Epic failure.

Service:  slow, inattentive, and had to be asked for everything.  They even forgot to serve the vinegar with the dumplings.  I raised a hand to ask one of the workers there for it, she saw me, and simply walked back into the kitchen.  How's that for service?

In summary, don't go here.

excerpts:
Fried tofu with vermicelli and pork soup
very salty and was not that good

shanghai gnen goh
very doughy and was probably the worst dish.
fried tofu.author: jason g.
fried tofu.review:
Let me try to describe this restaurant to you.  If the contestants on Top Chef have to open a makeshift restaurant in 24hrs.............this is how it would look like.  They have roughly 10 tables, no ventilation system, no paintings on the wall, Their maximum capacity is probably 26.  There's only one lady that takes the order and one assistant.  You ever go to a restaurant and feel like it is going to be a great restaurant but the service is going to be really bad?  Bingo.............this is it!!! This is what we had. 

Fried tofu with vermicelli and pork soup
very salty and was not that good

shanghai gnen goh
very doughy and was probably the worst dish.  I was getting very disappointed.

Fatty Pork
was very lean..........fatty pork that is lean? hahahah  It was very good

2 orders of shanghai dumplings
was decent........I've had better........but things are starting to look up

Pot stickers
taste like the shanghai dumplings but fried on the bottom with a different skin.  The pot stickers are gyoza size.  Very unique to see something like this.  I was very happy with this order.  It's getting better.


maun tao
deep fried bread with condense milk.  This is bad ass.  Great way to end the meal.

excerpts: The Buddha's Delight veggie combo was awesome, even though it didn't have the customary fried tofu pockets and glass noodles.
fried tofu.author: dj z.
fried tofu.review:
Wow, the place was incredibly clean, and even though the waitstaff was slow in such a small place, the food was worth it.

The sweet and sour pork was excellent! Flat thinly sliced pieces in a crispy batter, not too heavy or too sweet.

The Sesame chicken and dried fried chicken wings were way too sweet for my taste. The Buddha's Delight veggie combo was awesome, even though it didn't have the customary fried tofu pockets and glass noodles.

Will definitely come here again if I find myself near the beach soon!

excerpts:
- stir fried shrimp
- 5 spice beef (appetizer)
- bean thread noodles with cucumber
fried shrimp.author: Helen Y.
fried shrimp.review:
thanks to our real estate agent for introducing this place to us last nite.

our favorite dishes:
- vegetarian goose (served warm and with mushrooms)
- green onion pancake (the thin variety and not too greasy)
- shanghai dumplings (the hubby enjoyed them but we've had better)
- stir fried shrimp
- 5 spice beef (appetizer)
- bean thread noodles with cucumber (i loved this dish)

for dessert, enjoy the rice wine soup with black sesame balls.

excerpts: Focus on the Shanghai dishes menu, try the stir fried shrimp.
fried shrimp.author: Vivian L.
fried shrimp.review:
The Shanghai dumplings are DEELISH!  Better than Five Happiness, better than Shanghai Dumpling King up the block, better than Ding Tai Fung!  Focus on the Shanghai dishes menu, try the stir fried shrimp.  This resto passed the authenticity test by my Shanghainese family =)

Cash only spot.

excerpts: Got the steamed pork dumplings.
Very good.
Also had greeon onion pancakes which were crispy and chewy.
Also good quality.
steamed pork dumplings.author: Zachary H.
steamed pork dumplings.review: Came in for lunch. Got the steamed pork dumplings. Very good. Also had greeon onion pancakes which were crispy and chewy. Also good quality. The Dry Fried Chicken wings though. I love chicken wings. These were delicious. Crispy and flavorful with a sweet and slightly slicy sauce. The chicken was juicey and tender.  Awesome. Only problem was the service. Askes for water at the start of the meal. Got it at the end. Eh.

excerpts: They do offer the best steamed pork dumplings I've had in the city
steamed pork dumplings.author: Mike W.
steamed pork dumplings.review:
If possible, I would give it a 3.5.  I can't say with all my hear that "I'm a fan," but "A-OK" seems a bit low.  They do offer the best steamed pork dumplings I've had in the city (I didn't realize they go by XLB now), and the rest of the Chinese breakfast we had was tasty too.

Their Chinese donut was definitely fried to order, and was also the best I've had in the city.  The green onion pancake was the loser of the morning, but the silver threaded bun and the donut wrapped in rice (I forget the name) made up for it.  I didn't try the regular entrees, but I'm sure I'll be back for the Chinese breakfast.

excerpts: The steamed pork dumplings were okay as well .
Shanghai noodles were alright but didn't taste like anything special .
The noodles tasted like they were overcooked .
The onion pancake was really good though .
In fact , I'm munching on some right now .
The soy milk was good too
but it's really hot
so be sure to be careful drinking it !
Service-wise , the waitress barely ever makes any eye contact with the customers so it's really hard to get her attention .
But other than that , this place really isn't that bad .
Cheap , quick & acceptable Shanghainese food .
Only bad things about this place is that it's kind of small and there's no source of entertainment whatsoever .
And of course , the service could improve .
steamed pork dumplings.author: Eileen L.
steamed pork dumplings.review: Just came here today with my friend to try this place out . The Shanghai dumplings came in very tiny morsels . They were ehh .. alright , but the dumplings didn't really have much soup in them . Some had a little in them while some didn't have any in them at all . The steamed pork dumplings were okay as well . Shanghai noodles were alright but didn't taste like anything special . The noodles tasted like they were overcooked . The onion pancake was really good though . In fact , I'm munching on some right now . The soy milk was good too but it's really hot so be sure to be careful drinking it ! Service-wise , the waitress barely ever makes any eye contact with the customers so it's really hard to get her attention . But other than that , this place really isn't that bad . Cheap , quick & acceptable Shanghainese food . Only bad things about this place is that it's kind of small and there's no source of entertainment whatsoever . And of course , the service could improve .

excerpts: The green onion pancakes, vegetarian steamed dumplings, and vegetarian chow mein.
vegetarian steamed dumplings.author: Pina U.
vegetarian steamed dumplings.review:
One day after work - as I was hungry and craving Chinese food, I thought to venture over to this place... The one woman... She was extremely RUDE! ((It takes a lot to upset me.)) I received no acknowledgement upon entering the restaurant. Still, I walked up to her and kindly asked for a menu. I conveyed that I was ordering for "HERE". She seemed rushed. Anyhow I sat myself down after ordering three items. By the way, she did not offer water or tea to me - though I wasn't worried as I happened to have a full bottle of water with me. Though it was slightly bothersome to watch her bring food to people who had entered the restaurant much AFTER me. I waited... Waited... Also, it was so hard to flag her down to inquire re: the status of my order - as she made no eye contact with me and rushed to/from the back. 

Anyway, 45+ minutes later - she brought out my order via packed containers in a plastic bag... WHAT?! Again I reported I had ordered for "HERE" - and this time she replied with something along the lines of "I thought you ordered to go". She did NOT apologize for the misunderstanding. Note - when I'm hungry, I get irritated... Internally, I was so frustrated! Anyway, as I just wanted to get out of there (!!!), I paid (no tip as unbeknown to me, it ended up being to go), grabbed the food, and left (w/o getting soy sauce). 

I'm giving one star as the food was edible... The green onion pancakes, vegetarian steamed dumplings, and vegetarian chow mein. 

I wish I went elsewhere... Sadly, this place has horrible service... 

As one of the other reviews mentioned, I wish I spoke Chinese. Note, I was the only Indian person in the restaurant at the time. Perhaps the woman thought I was a lost tourist?

excerpts: We had the Shanghai steamed baby dumplings, vegetarian steamed dumplings,Salted pork with vegetables rice clay pot & the Tender chicken in Shanghai style noodle soup.
The food was mediocre at best.
The restroom is upstairs, but I had to ask because there is no sign for the restroom.
They need to have a sign up saying that it is upstairs.
vegetarian steamed dumplings.author: Jerry C.
vegetarian steamed dumplings.review: We spent the day at Baker Beach and originally was on the way to Purple Kow ,when we go hungry, so we walked around and found this place. Looked good from the outside, so we went in.  Upon entering no one greeted us. Elm E. made a comment like that here also. The only reason I think they didn't greet us was because the manager was training a new employee, but she failed at training her. Not greeting the customer, big mistake. We had the Shanghai steamed baby dumplings, vegetarian steamed dumplings,Salted pork with vegetables rice clay pot & the Tender chicken in Shanghai style noodle soup. The food was mediocre at best.   The restroom is upstairs, but I had to ask because there is no sign for the restroom. They need to have a sign up saying that it is upstairs.

excerpts:
it's a mysterious practice they have of only giving it to you with the other menu (straight american chinese food?)--so some people may never even see it (esp. if you order take out)

update: since this review I've tried a few other notable dishes: the Vegetarian Goose (with shitake mushrooms) is delicious as are the Vegetarian Steamed Dumplings.
vegetarian steamed dumplings.author: Liza B.
vegetarian steamed dumplings.review:
Why anyone would rate this great little place less than 4 stars is a mystery to me--perhaps they ordered the wrong things or maybe they came from outside this neighborhood...Yes I guess if I bussed, biked or drove over here from the Mission, I would probably not give it 5 stars, but this yummy, inexpensive restaurant is in MY neighborhood where good restaurants are far outnumbered by really, really dismal ones. 

My first favorite restaurant in this stretch has always been Miki's right next door...but now I have TWO new favorites on Balboa. Yu Zen and Shanghai House. 

What did I eat there that made me this excited? Well, the first thing I tried, I ate four or five times before I moved on to anything else and that was the Kung Pao chicken. I tried only that partly because I liked it so much, partly because I got it at least 4 times to go--you can't order from the "Shanghai" menu on take out orders--and partly because if you order two orders + rice for two you can feed 4 people (take out) for $20! And that's eating really stand-out Kung Pao--smoky peppers and smoked tofu, lots of veggies (mostly zucchini but it's good here) and tasty chicken. Just right. 

My interest in Chinese Food in my neighborhood (exception of all exceptions: Ton Kiang for brunch) has seriously waned ~ it seemed every time I went for Chinese the last  few years I ate something that was too greasy, too sweet or just not memorable. 

Talk about memorable! the Shanghai style Vegetable Soup with hand cut noodles I had here last weekend has been stuck in my savory, sensory memory ever since and I just can't shake it. Out of all three dishes I ate that meal (my friend and I were hungry and determined to sample more of the menu) the said soup was actually the least "exciting" dish,  but for some reason it's the one that won out as top memorable sense that I can still "taste". I was actually most "excited" about the Bok Choy with Wheat Gluten Dumplings. This was amazingly good and yummy with a delicious sauce soaking the dumplings and the perfectly sized baby bok choy (you don't have to make a slippery slimy fool of yourself with these as you do with typically sized bok choy). Plus I am a sucker for really yummy "meat alternatives". 

And then to show that I am also a sucker for some meats, I also highly recommend the Tea Smoked Duck. It's so delicious! and for someone like me who doesn't eat meat other than poultry or fish, Duck prepared like this is as tasty and decadent as any pork dish might be (read: fatty and delicious and crispy).

So yes, you should try this place. But make sure you look at the Shanghai Menu. it's a mysterious practice they have of only giving it to you with the other menu (straight american chinese food?)--so some people may never even see it (esp. if you order take out)

update: since this review I've tried a few other notable dishes: the Vegetarian Goose (with shitake mushrooms) is delicious as are the Vegetarian Steamed Dumplings. The Mu Shu Vegetables were just right, too. The Vegetable Soup with hand-cut noodles wasn't as exciting as the first time I had it, but that happens sometimes ; ) Obviously plenty for a vegetarian to eat, although I'm not vegetairian. 

update #2: Now that I eat all meat, I can rate the Shanghai pork dumplings too--more delicate and nicer than the (notorious) ones up the street. And the Golden Prawns are my new favorite dish! Yum Yum

update #3: for some reason, after all of these years, I had never ordered the chicken wings until sometime the end of this last year. Oh my! Now it's the new 'must have' --hot, spicy, sweet, crunchy--it's a meal and dessert all at once. Leftovers that we have been known to fight over the next day ("hey you took two pieces!") Chicken crack.

excerpts: The savory soy soup, the vegetarian goose, the fried buns, the various kinds of noodles, are some of the many of our favorites.
vegetarian goose.author: Gene L.
vegetarian goose.review: I'm a regular here. My wife and I came very often. Now I bring my daughters and grandchildren here. They love the food here also. I loved every dish I've tried here. But you need to come try and to discover your own favorites. The chicken wings, better than San Tong or anywhere else. Their siao long bow is the best in a SF. The savory soy soup, the vegetarian goose, the fried buns, the various kinds of noodles, are some of the many of our favorites.

excerpts: They also accidentally gave us the vegetarian goose and when we pointed out that we did not order it...
the lady kept asking us if we wanted to keep it.
Which we did not want or we would've ordered it to begin with.
vegetarian goose.author: Mei C.
vegetarian goose.review:
Came here for lunch since we planned on going across the street to Purple Kow for drinks after wards.

Upon entering the restaurant, the female waitress/hostess was on her cell phone and ignored us. We stood there like idiots not sure if we were supposed to seat ourselves or to continue to wait. After what seems like an eternity (which is probably more like 5 minutes) with the already seated patrons looking at us... the chef (male worker) came out and noticed us. He motioned us to a table and started getting the attention the the female waitress to get off her phone. She looked irritated that he was telling her to get off her cellphone. 

Anyways... we ordered Shanghai Dumplings (xiao long bao), Hand Cut noodle and Potstickers.

The Shanghai Dumplings were ok. I prefer Shanghai Dumpling Kings a few blocks away more.

The Hand Cut Noodle was ok. Had a lot of cabbage and not enough noodle. 

The Potstickers were average.

They also accidentally gave us the vegetarian goose and when we pointed out that we did not order it... the lady kept asking us if we wanted to keep it. Which we did not want or we would've ordered it to begin with. At least she didn't charge us for it. 

All in all... I will not go back since Shanghai Dumpling King is only a few blocks away and taste much better and cheaper.

excerpts: Vegetarian Goose.
Delicious!
Similar to a dim sum, rolled tofu skin dish, except this is crispy and vegetarian.
Pig Knuckle, we opted for the salt & pepper variant.
Really good.
Had enough to take home.
We'll come back, try more dishes.
Will not order the XLB again.
vegetarian goose.author: Geordie E.
vegetarian goose.review:
Ordered the dry fried chicken wings, it IS much more flavorful than San Tung.
It's better. 
XLB, I've had better, the skin was thick yet fragile. Be careful when picking up. 
Vegetarian Goose. Delicious! Similar to a dim sum, rolled tofu skin dish, except this is crispy and vegetarian. 
Pig Knuckle, we opted for the salt & pepper variant. Really good. Had enough to take home. 
We'll come back, try more dishes. Will not order the XLB again.

excerpts: The vegetarian goose is excellent.
The tofu is crisp, the mushrooms are perfectly soft and chewy and the sauce is a good mixture of sweet and salty.
Also tried the green onion pancake which was flaky and crispy without being dry at all.
vegetarian goose.author: Tim W.
vegetarian goose.review:
This place is like San Tung, but with more to offer than just Dry Fried Chicken Wings.

The xiaolong bao have good flavor but are slightly lacking in broth. The vegetarian goose is excellent. The tofu is crisp, the mushrooms are perfectly soft and chewy and the sauce is a good mixture of sweet and salty. Also tried the green onion pancake which was flaky and crispy without being dry at all. And finally the dry fried chicken wings are on par with San Tung with a good combination of crunch, sweet, salty, and spicy.

excerpts: Their vegetarian goose and their rice roll (fan tuan) are two of my favorites when it comes to breakfast items/small eats.
vegetarian goose.author: Jonas T.
vegetarian goose.review:
Overall, good food! Soup dumplings weren't the best, but I liked everything else. Their vegetarian goose and their rice roll (fan tuan) are two of my favorites when it comes to breakfast items/small eats.

JONASAPPROVED!

excerpts: Vegetarian goose was better than expected.
vegetarian goose.author: Jennifer T.
vegetarian goose.review:
First time here with my cousin. It is a small hole in the wall but the food is pretty good

Got here around 7 pm and got seated at the last table and just missed the crowd.

Dry fried chicken wings were crispy and yes almost as good as the ones at San Tung across the park.

Sting beans with shrimp was yummy.

Vegetarian goose was better than expected.  Warm and crispy.

The lion head in the claypot was delicious.

Highly recommend you to give this place a try .

excerpts:
our favorite dishes:
- vegetarian goose (served warm and with mushrooms)
- green onion pancake (the thin variety and not too greasy)
- shanghai dumplings (the hubby enjoyed them
but we've had better)
vegetarian goose.author: Helen Y.
vegetarian goose.review:
thanks to our real estate agent for introducing this place to us last nite.

our favorite dishes:
- vegetarian goose (served warm and with mushrooms)
- green onion pancake (the thin variety and not too greasy)
- shanghai dumplings (the hubby enjoyed them but we've had better)
- stir fried shrimp
- 5 spice beef (appetizer)
- bean thread noodles with cucumber (i loved this dish)

for dessert, enjoy the rice wine soup with black sesame balls.

excerpts:
Vegetarian Goose
2.

Vegetarian dumplings
3.
The vegetarian goose was sweet and salty, dumplings were warm and delicious, and the bean curd salad was refreshing.
I'm glad I only live a few blocks away, because I am all for trying out more of their dishes!
To tell you the truth, service is not all that great
and it's cash only,
but hey, the food's what gets me
so I'm good!
vegetarian goose.author: Liz V.
vegetarian goose.review:
Danced myself back to this restaurant because I was down for some vegetarian food. If you follow me here in the wonderful world of Yelp, you'll know by now that I love me some vegetables (and fruits!). So with that said, I've read many reviews about Shanghai House's vegetarian friendly dishes.

So I came in, sat by the window and ordered:

1. Vegetarian Goose
2. Vegetarian dumplings
3. Bean curd salad

And let me tell you... I use to not enjoy Chinese restaurants for the mere fact that almost every dish I know of is swimming in canola oil. It still holds true to this day, and believe me, this place is no exception. But what I realize is that I love food that originates from Asia, mostly because I love that their dishes tend to incorporate lots of vegetables.

Shanghai House deserves a four star rating for this reason.

Sure, I had their sinful fried chicken not too long ago, but let's not think about that now. I am well aware of my cravings and I know when to stop.

What I do know is that 3 vegetarian dishes all to myself fills me up. Who says vegetarians and vegans are hungry all the time??? I am not one, but hey, I know for a fact that if i wanted vegetables for dinner, I know I have to eat at least a pound before I feel completely satisfied.

Back to the food, which is the main reason for this review. If you haven't figured it out by now, I LOVE it. The vegetarian goose was sweet and salty, dumplings were warm and delicious, and the bean curd salad was refreshing. I'm glad I only live a few blocks away, because I am all for trying out more of their dishes! To tell you the truth, service is not all that great and it's cash only, but hey, the food's what gets me so I'm good!

excerpts: Neatly assembled, the vegetarian goose ($4.25) appetizer is a great starter.
Tender cake make from many thin layers of tofu skin, with a pan fried crispy top, wraps in a meaty shitake mushroom filling.
A slight drizzle of red vinegar provide a tang enhancer.
vegetarian goose.author: Rayfil W.
vegetarian goose.review:
Along the quiet neighborhood of outer Richmond, a small packet of restaurants sits firmly on Balboa Street. Despite a cult following at Shanghai Dumpling King just a few blocks away, Shanghai House surprised customers with amazing food and clean décor. Formerly the chef at Wu Kong, chef/owner Kam Yuen Lu successfully translates a few banquet style dishes in his neighborhood restaurant.

Ambiance. 
In the twenty six seat restaurant, the ambiance is fit for a cozy dinner with friends. An all glass front allows customer a clear view of Richmond neighborhood. Clean white walls and bright ceiling lights create a minimalist décor allowing the food dishes play center stage. Dishes are served handsomely over a table filled with a scenic nature background.

Food.
Shanghainess cooking showcases a tad sweet in taste compared to their regional counterparts. I start off the meal with a few orders of cold plate dishes. Neatly assembled, the vegetarian goose ($4.25) appetizer is a great starter. Tender cake make from many thin layers of tofu skin, with a pan fried crispy top, wraps in a meaty shitake mushroom filling. A slight drizzle of red vinegar provide a tang enhancer. Neatly fanned across the plate, the five spice beef ($4.95) was a disappointment.

The beef lacked flavor and was dry. Served in a bamboo steamer, the pork dumpling (minced pork filling wrapped in a soft house made wonton like skin) revived my taste buds with a burst of soup and tender filling. Braised fish with white wine sauce ($9.95) feature tender flounder. Giving the dish character, crunchy wood ear fungus compliments the soft fish. My least favorite dish was the rice cake - $5.95. Seemingly presented without care, chewy rice cakes are work-tossed with shredded pork and Napa cabbage.

The stew pork ($7.25) stole the show. Each thinly pork slice flaunts the dual textures of savory meat with a fatty cap. Hiding under the buttery pork, dried vegetables provide a slight savory note. The dark maple sauce brings the entire dish together. An order of fluffy white rich diffused the sweetness.
Having been here previously for brunch, the savory rice roll ($2.50) warms up the stomach. Resembling a sushi roll, sticky rice wraps around dried shredded pork and vegetables. The sweet soy bean milk ($1.25) makes a great breakfast drink. The savory soy bean milk is an acquired taste.

Dried vegetables, friend Chinese doughnut, along with a drizzle of chilli oil swim in the silky milk. Cut into triangular pizza slices and fried till golden brown, onion pancakes ($3.95) highlights the aroma of fried onion. Enriched in a dark sweet sauce, Shanghai style pan fried noodle (noodles stir fried with cabbage and shredded prok-$5.50) gives patrons a taste of chewy noodles that rounds out a dish.

While chef/owner Kam Yuen Lu is busy in the kitchen, wife Teresa Hai serves patrons in the front of the house. Hai said, "the most challenging part of owning a restaurant is finding local fresh ingredients." Another dish I have yet to try but recommend is the pig's knuckle which must be ordered one day in advance.

excerpts: Vegetarian goose
- I honestly cannot tell you why it's called goose-
I think it's made of some tofu skin.
I'm allergic but still order it anyway -
that's how delicious it is, really.
vegetarian goose.author: Betty W.
vegetarian goose.review:
How do I express my love-hate relationship with Shanghai House?  I've loved their food since they opened, but the service drives me absolutely insane!!  There's only one woman working as the cashier/waitress/server/busboy; with all those responsibilities, you would think she's superwoman.......but she's not.  The service is ridiculously slow and the food takes ages to arrive.  That brings us to the sole reason why I continue to go to Shanghai House: the food is amazing.

1. Shanghai dumplings - 10 in each order, each perfectly plump and full of juices...soup I meant. (5/5)
2. Vegetarian goose - I honestly cannot tell you why it's called goose- I think it's made of some tofu skin.  I'm allergic but still order it anyway - that's how delicious it is, really. (5/5)
3. Dry fried chicken wings - amazingly sweet and spicy and flavorful.  Definitely up to par with the infamous San Tung chicken.  Sadly, it is a little inconsistent - It's sometimes better (spicier and sweeter) and sometimes worse (saltier) than San Tung's dry fried chicken. (4/5)
4. Hand-cut noodles - tasted like a chow mein type dish.  Noodles were thick and uneven.  I enjoyed it, but it was a little too greasy. (3/5)
4. Chinese donut - don't do it!  Really, it's not because it's disgustingly unhealthy and deep fried, but because it looks and tastes like it.  It looks kind of like a churro, minus the cinnamon and sugar and amazingness.  Imagine a long brick of dough, injected with butter and lard, and deep-fried.  (0/5)

Give yourself an extra 10 mins to find parking, and an additional 30 mins to wait for your food.

excerpts: I had the vegetarian goose.
It was amazing.
Can't wait to go back for more!
vegetarian goose.author: Eva UnTiger S.
vegetarian goose.review:
I went here for the first time and loved it.
I had the vegetarian goose. It was amazing.
Can't wait to go back for more!

excerpts: Try their vegetarian goose or their homemade noodles (Shanghai or hand cut) or their sweet black sesame balls in rice wine.
What about their Shanghai dumplings? as good as Yank Sing's, but, ehi
,  3X cheaper!
vegetarian goose.author: Andrea L.
vegetarian goose.review:
Guys! I have been there five times and I consider this place one of the best Chinese around. Try their vegetarian goose or their homemade noodles (Shanghai or hand cut) or their sweet black sesame balls in rice wine.  What about their Shanghai dumplings? as good as Yank Sing's, but, ehi,  3X cheaper! 
Monstrously good ratio quality/price.  

It's a real shame that their average rating is only 3.5. They truly deserve much more.

excerpts: Vegetarian Goose: mushroom covered in tofu, fried and covered in sweet sauce.

Delish
Shanghai Dumplings: Very similar to shanghai dumpling king except a little less flavorful and the sauce isn't as good.
Vegetarian Dumplings: Pretty good, not great, mostly cabbage with a bit of mushroom & tofu
Pork Bao: stewed pork with veggies (as opposed to the BBQ variety).
I really liked these because they had much better filling to dough ratio then any bao I've had before.
Red Bean Bao:
Soooo delicious.
What a great dessert!
The verdict:
I think I'll always check Dumpling King first, but this joint is a great second choice.
vegetarian goose.author: Lauren T.
vegetarian goose.review:
I was very curious to try a new shanghai dumpling place (just in case the wait for my beloved Shanghai Dumpling King is ever too long). 
We shared:
Vegetarian Goose: mushroom covered in tofu, fried and covered in sweet sauce. Delish
Shanghai Dumplings: Very similar to shanghai dumpling king except a little less flavorful and the sauce isn't as good. 
Vegetarian Dumplings: Pretty good, not great, mostly cabbage with a bit of mushroom & tofu
Pork Bao: stewed pork with veggies (as opposed to the BBQ variety). I really liked these because they had much better filling to dough ratio then any bao I've had before. 
Red Bean Bao: Soooo delicious. What a great dessert! 
The verdict: I think I'll always check Dumpling King first, but this joint is a great second choice.

excerpts:
On par with Shanghai Dumpling House 

Ricecake, sweet or savory soy bean  milk, vegetarian goose, wonton, and other dumplings are all authentic.
vegetarian goose.author: Cin T.
vegetarian goose.review:
Authentic Shanghainese food.  Cash Only

There are 2 menu - be sure to ask for both.

Shanghainese Menu 
Pork Knuckle (Special - should call to order in advance since it takes a long time to cook) - A big chunk of slow roasted , flavorful and tender meat. 

XLB - As good as it gets.  On par with Shanghai Dumpling House 

Ricecake, sweet or savory soy bean  milk, vegetarian goose, wonton, and other dumplings are all authentic.   

Chinese Menu
Dry fried chicken wings, fish, and shrimp - all very good and on par with San Tung

Hand pulled Noodles with black bean sauce and spicy dan dan noodles reminds me of San Tung.  Large portion and decent price.

Service/Ambience - Small restaurant with 20-30 seats.  Service can be slow when it's a full house.  

Before this place opened, I use to go to the Shanghai Dumpling King.  Now I prefer this place because it is less crowded, cleaner, and has really good chicken wings.

excerpts: The rating is based mainy on their vegetarian goose, a fried outer layer of bean curd with mushroom filling, which was cheap, tasty, and filling.
vegetarian goose.author: Marsha Z.
vegetarian goose.review:
The rating is based mainy on their vegetarian goose, a fried outer layer of bean curd with mushroom filling, which was cheap, tasty, and filling.  Everything else was up to par, like their fried rice and my friend's beef and noodle concoction.  

The bargain prices and aloof waitress might have you think you're dining at "just another Chinese joint", but the food is a notch above.  It's deep in the Richmond, but I wouldn't hesitate to return.

excerpts: I can only report that, in addition to the excellent pompano, the vegetarian goose tastes nothing like goose, and looks even less like goose, but is very tasty, the sesame chicken is one of the best sweet fried preparations of anything I've had, the spareribs are good in a sauce that might be a little bit too rich, and the house special eggplant is excellent.
vegetarian goose.author: Spike S.
vegetarian goose.review:
At Shanghai House, you get a good meal at a good price.  And it's in a clean restaurant with a clean bathroom, which isn't always true in this part of town.

But first, something to remember before you get there: CASH ONLY.  Fortunately, there is a BoA about four doors down the street, but it's better not to have to run out at the end of the meal to get some cash.

Another thing to know is that there are TWO MENUS.  They may bring you both menus, but you have to look closely because they look almost the same.  If you only have the gringo menu (no jellyfish in the appetizer section is a sure indicator of the gringo menu), ask for the other menu.  And you can call it The Other Menu, this is well understood.

Now why do you want The Other Menu unless you like jellyfish and pig's feet? (I like both, but that's not the point here.)  Maybe because you LIKE FISH.  There's no fish on The Gringo Menu, only on The Other Menu.  And the fried pompano with spicy sauce, is fish worth having.  If you're not used to cooked whole fish, it might be frustrating at first, but it's worth the effort.  My only complaint is that the fish is a bit small.  Afterwards, you have this beautiful fish skeleton with a head and tail, I wish I had brought my camera.

There are other fish dishes and a lot of other dishes on The Other Menu, but I forgot to bring all my relatives so we could try them.  I can only report that, in addition to the excellent pompano, the vegetarian goose tastes nothing like goose, and looks even less like goose, but is very tasty, the sesame chicken is one of the best sweet fried preparations of anything I've had, the spareribs are good in a sauce that might be a little bit too rich, and the house special eggplant is excellent.

The food is incredibly hot when it comes to the table, it's only about forty steps from the wok to the table and the kitchen doesn't have any real staging area (you see it when you go the bathroom), so let it sit before you burn your mouth.  The tea is good and the fortune cookies are fortune cookies.

, there was juice, not bad, but not 100%

vegetarian goose.author: Eva L.
vegetarian goose.review:
The food was okay, some of the dishes were better than others.  We had a lot of people so we had the opportunity to try quite a bit.

* Xiaolong bao - The skin was okay, there was juice, not bad, but not 100%
* Vegetarian goose - Perfectly crisp and great flavor!  
* Tea soaked duck - It was not bad, it had a smoked flavor. It only comes with 4 buns, they looked softer than it tasted. Order more if you have more than 4 people
* Green Onion Pancakes- Just pass, it is very doughy, not flaky and crispy
* Shanghai Noodles - Was saucy, i believe it is supposed to be cooked dryer. the noodles were not good at all, very disappointing.
* Tan Tan Mein - it was good, not bad. much better than the Shanghai Noodles
* Pig's knuckle - you must pre-order from my understanding. We had the crispy one, it was fatty and good!
* Stewed pork with preserved vegetable - Okay, not sure if this is really the name, but it is a stewed pork with sweet preserved vegetables, this was good too! 

The service could of been better, the lady (waitress) wasn't really nice. place is small, so reservations are recommended with big groups. They did take our group of 10. 
last but not least, BYOB! =)

excerpts:
it's a mysterious practice they have of only giving it to you with the other menu (straight american chinese food?)--so some people may never even see it (esp. if you order take out)

update: since this review I've tried a few other notable dishes: the Vegetarian Goose (with shitake mushrooms) is delicious as are the Vegetarian Steamed Dumplings.
vegetarian goose.author: Liza B.
vegetarian goose.review:
Why anyone would rate this great little place less than 4 stars is a mystery to me--perhaps they ordered the wrong things or maybe they came from outside this neighborhood...Yes I guess if I bussed, biked or drove over here from the Mission, I would probably not give it 5 stars, but this yummy, inexpensive restaurant is in MY neighborhood where good restaurants are far outnumbered by really, really dismal ones. 

My first favorite restaurant in this stretch has always been Miki's right next door...but now I have TWO new favorites on Balboa. Yu Zen and Shanghai House. 

What did I eat there that made me this excited? Well, the first thing I tried, I ate four or five times before I moved on to anything else and that was the Kung Pao chicken. I tried only that partly because I liked it so much, partly because I got it at least 4 times to go--you can't order from the "Shanghai" menu on take out orders--and partly because if you order two orders + rice for two you can feed 4 people (take out) for $20! And that's eating really stand-out Kung Pao--smoky peppers and smoked tofu, lots of veggies (mostly zucchini but it's good here) and tasty chicken. Just right. 

My interest in Chinese Food in my neighborhood (exception of all exceptions: Ton Kiang for brunch) has seriously waned ~ it seemed every time I went for Chinese the last  few years I ate something that was too greasy, too sweet or just not memorable. 

Talk about memorable! the Shanghai style Vegetable Soup with hand cut noodles I had here last weekend has been stuck in my savory, sensory memory ever since and I just can't shake it. Out of all three dishes I ate that meal (my friend and I were hungry and determined to sample more of the menu) the said soup was actually the least "exciting" dish,  but for some reason it's the one that won out as top memorable sense that I can still "taste". I was actually most "excited" about the Bok Choy with Wheat Gluten Dumplings. This was amazingly good and yummy with a delicious sauce soaking the dumplings and the perfectly sized baby bok choy (you don't have to make a slippery slimy fool of yourself with these as you do with typically sized bok choy). Plus I am a sucker for really yummy "meat alternatives". 

And then to show that I am also a sucker for some meats, I also highly recommend the Tea Smoked Duck. It's so delicious! and for someone like me who doesn't eat meat other than poultry or fish, Duck prepared like this is as tasty and decadent as any pork dish might be (read: fatty and delicious and crispy).

So yes, you should try this place. But make sure you look at the Shanghai Menu. it's a mysterious practice they have of only giving it to you with the other menu (straight american chinese food?)--so some people may never even see it (esp. if you order take out)

update: since this review I've tried a few other notable dishes: the Vegetarian Goose (with shitake mushrooms) is delicious as are the Vegetarian Steamed Dumplings. The Mu Shu Vegetables were just right, too. The Vegetable Soup with hand-cut noodles wasn't as exciting as the first time I had it, but that happens sometimes ; ) Obviously plenty for a vegetarian to eat, although I'm not vegetairian. 

update #2: Now that I eat all meat, I can rate the Shanghai pork dumplings too--more delicate and nicer than the (notorious) ones up the street. And the Golden Prawns are my new favorite dish! Yum Yum

update #3: for some reason, after all of these years, I had never ordered the chicken wings until sometime the end of this last year. Oh my! Now it's the new 'must have' --hot, spicy, sweet, crunchy--it's a meal and dessert all at once. Leftovers that we have been known to fight over the next day ("hey you took two pieces!") Chicken crack.

excerpts: The vegetarian goose (crisp tofu skin with mushroom filling) is really delicious.
Spring rolls are good too.
As with the rice cake, steamed dumplings, and the yan du xian (it's soup with an intense flavor of smoked ham).
Decor is simple and clean.
Finally, a Chinese restaurant that does not write menu items on a strip of red paper and tape it on the walls like it's decoration!
vegetarian goose.author: Aila L.
vegetarian goose.review:
This place is waaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyy out there in Richmond....but worth the drive!  The food here is pretty good and inexpensive.  The vegetarian goose (crisp tofu skin with mushroom filling) is really delicious.  Spring rolls are good too.   As with the rice cake, steamed dumplings, and the yan du xian (it's soup with an intense flavor of smoked ham).
 
Decor is simple and clean.  Finally, a Chinese restaurant that does not write menu items on a strip of red paper and tape it on the walls like it's decoration!

excerpts: -I enjoyed the vegetarian goose.
vegetarian goose.author: Sara G.
vegetarian goose.review:
I live near this place and will almost certainly eat here again, so it's possible my opinion will improve, but after two visits, I would say:
-I prefer the dumplings at Shanghai Dumpling King up the street, for their thinner wrapper and better flavor. This is not in any way an authoritative or expert opinion, just my preference. But these were reasonably tasty too.
-The sweet and sour sparerib sauce is interesting, very dark and almost coffee/syrup like. I found it had a bit too much charcoal taste to it, for my liking.
-The handcut noodles with shrimp were garlicky and pretty good.
-I enjoyed the vegetarian goose.

Service was pretty prompt when we were there on a weeknight, even though the place was busy. The place is clean and bright, as others have noted, if small.

The fact that they handed my friend and I the boring Chinese standards menu on my first visit there irritates me even more than being given a fork rather than chopsticks. I never would have known they served anything worth eating if I hadn't seen an article mentioning a second menu.

Overall, I give an edge to Shanghai Dumpling King-- but this place is closer, so I suspect laziness will help even the score!

excerpts: I love the shanghai dumplings and vegetarian goose (su arr) here!
I noticed that the dumplings are better if you go at certain times.
One time
I went for a late lunch in the mid afternoon, and the dumplings were all deflated but every time we go for dinner, it's great!
The lady doesn't really tend to your every need at all times but you have to understand that she's the only one out there!
So she's totally outnumbered.
She isn't very friendly at first
but if you go there enough, she'll warm up to you.
I tried to brush up on my mandarin with her and practice ordering the three things I always get: 2 shanghai dumplings, 1 vegetarian goose, and 1 cucumber bean curd salad.
Very reasonably priced.
I'd recommend it!
Just don't expect to be super pampered with exceptional service but expect to be satisfied with a great meal!
vegetarian goose.author: Tu L.
vegetarian goose.review:
I love this place! I've been here so many times since Shanghai Dumpling King failed me thrice in a row! 
Every time I come here, the lady server/host looks really depressed and hella tired.  I feel bad for her to have to be there all the time and dealing with the same crap everyday but she runs a great place!

It's a nice, small and clean ( for the most part) place to have a quiet meal.  It really does seem like she's the ONLY person working there even though they've got like 5 people in the back.  I love the shanghai dumplings and vegetarian goose (su arr) here! I noticed that the dumplings are better if you go at certain times.  One time  I went for a late lunch in the mid afternoon, and the dumplings were all deflated but every time we go for dinner, it's great! 
The lady doesn't really tend to your every need at all times but you have to understand that she's the only one out there! So she's totally outnumbered.  She isn't very friendly at first but if you go there enough, she'll warm up to you.  I tried to brush up on my mandarin with her and practice ordering the three things I always get: 2 shanghai dumplings, 1 vegetarian goose, and 1 cucumber bean curd salad.   Very reasonably priced.  I'd recommend it!  Just don't expect to be super pampered with exceptional service but expect to be satisfied with a great meal!
