The Xiaolong Bao was definitely not as good.  However, the dirty vegetarian goose was pretty good and the savory rice roll almost reminded me of the savory rice rolls you get in Taiwan.  The portions here are on the smaller side.  I am fat so I need more.  I also prefer to have a fat wallet, but this place stole most of money because it so fatty expensive.  I actually almost forgot I ate at this place.  I will be down the street back to my usual dumpling king with the rest of the fattys.

excerpts: our usual order: dumplings (2 orders), five spice beef, green onion pancakes (varies, but usually tip top), vegetarian goose (pressed tofu skin) stuffed with mushrooms, chinese style sweet/sour pork - read:
Chinese style, not the orange goop, special noodle (knife cut - their speciality).
i usually roll out the door and into the car.
a walk around the block (okay, several blocks), I am ready for another dumpling run.
Run, do not walk there.
You won't be sorry!
vegetarian goose.author: Sonia C.
vegetarian goose.review: Outrageous "shiu long boa", or little dragon dumplings.  scary good.  our usual order: dumplings (2 orders), five spice beef, green onion pancakes (varies, but usually tip top), vegetarian goose (pressed tofu skin) stuffed with mushrooms, chinese style sweet/sour pork - read: Chinese style, not the orange goop, special noodle (knife cut - their speciality).  i usually roll out the door and into the car.  a walk around the block (okay, several blocks), I am ready for another dumpling run.  Run, do not walk there.  You won't be sorry!

excerpts: Also, the "vegetarian goose," which is made of crispy tofu skins fried with mushrooms inside and a sweet sauce drizzled over the top is extraordinary.
I am usually not into vegetarian dishes, especially when they pretend to be meat substitute, but this is not remotely in the league of the aforementioned.
The atmosphere is plain, brightly lit and there is an air of greatness in cooking.
The front is all glass and the neon marquis of the Balboa Theatre across the street is all the artwork one could hope for.
vegetarian goose.author: Barbara S.
vegetarian goose.review: Shanghai House has become my favorite restaurant in S.F. The dumplings are quite simply the most delicate and tasty I have ever had. The dipping sauce has shards of fresh ginger and is perfect. Also, the "vegetarian goose," which is made of crispy tofu skins fried with mushrooms inside and a sweet sauce drizzled over the top is extraordinary. I am usually not into vegetarian dishes, especially when they pretend to be meat substitute, but this is not remotely in the league of the aforementioned. The atmosphere is plain, brightly lit and there is an air of greatness in cooking. The front is all glass and the neon marquis of the Balboa Theatre across the street is all the artwork one could hope for.

excerpts: The vegetarian goose was very good too.
vegetarian goose.author: vernice l.
vegetarian goose.review:
My family checked out this place for our regular Friday night dinner.  The 9 of us tried a variety of dishes and I was impressed, esp. with its price. 

This place is fairly small so make reservations. They pulled 4 tables together for our family. The place was packed all night.  

Service was so-so. There is only one waitress and she looked stressed out and angry most of the night.  I felt sorry for some of the patrons because their food took FOREVER to come out probably because the kitchen was cooking all of our stuff. There were tons of people in and out for take out orders as well. 

Their "little dragon buns" were really good. There was juice in each one. The vegetarian goose was very good too.

excerpts: Excellent dumplings and other dishes, especially the clay pots, vegetarian goose, veggie dumplings, chicken wings (deep fried crispy chicken wings), green beans.
However, there are 2 different menus so make sure you look at both menus.
Also, it helps to look around the room and see what looks good and maybe even ask other customers because the server is not helpful at all.
There are a lot of dishes that I've never heard of on their menu.
vegetarian goose.author: Melanie G.
vegetarian goose.review:
Excellent dumplings and other dishes, especially the clay pots, vegetarian goose, veggie dumplings, chicken wings (deep fried crispy chicken wings), green beans.  However, there are 2 different menus so make sure you look at both menus.  Also, it helps to look around the room and see what looks good and maybe even ask other customers because the server is not helpful at all.  There are a lot of dishes that I've never heard of on their menu.  When we first came we didn't know what to order and one of the dumplings that we ordered turned out to be just balls of dough that are used in a bau.  

Pluses: Great food other than simply dumplings.  If you want dishes other than dumplings then go here, if you want mainly dumplings and faster service then go to Shanghai Dumpling King down the street.  Pretty cheap (dishes are under $10) and BYOB- you can bring your own wine or beer.  They will open the bottle of wine and give you wine glasses for free.

Cons: Service is very slow and not helpful.  I don't think that she speaks much English or cares about the customers.  If I scored this place on service only, it would get a 1 star, but if you have time to wait, the food is worth it.

excerpts: the vegetarian goose
( i AM NOT a vegetarian- far from it!) was amazing.
a light tofu and mushroom dish with unexpected delectable flavor.
the dumplings were pretty good.
not the best i ever had, but better than most.
vegetarian goose.author: Missniche W.
vegetarian goose.review:
wow! yuuuuummmy! 
i couldn't give this place 5 stars and here's why- a tsingtao is always fantastic with a chinese meal and there is no liquor license. also, the single waitress for the restaurant was just not nice. i'm well aware of cultural differences, however service is service and she would not smile, was not attentive, paid  no heed to the order of dishes or amount of space available on the table for food. i also noticed it was not just my table (me being black and my cohorts being caucasian)- but she was equal opportunity cold, withdrawn and indifferent to every table- oh, and ps- there is no life or decoration at shanghai house. i think one plant. luckily my 5 companions were worthy of paying attention only to my immediate surroundings...and the food.

the food was phenomenal! the vegetarian goose ( i AM NOT a vegetarian- far from it!) was amazing. a light tofu and mushroom dish with unexpected delectable flavor. the dumplings were pretty good. not the best i ever had, but better than most. the potstickers were...not good potstickers. more like funny shaped shanghais, crispy on the bottom. the chinese eggplant, chicken and shrimp dish left me wanting more and the sesame chicken was perfectly crisp and saturated. the fish and shittake mushrooms (our best guess was some kind of bass) left my mouth humbled, thinking that i had had it better before. all in all, i will definitely go back and enjoy the food immensely.

i should mention that we brought a 6-pack of brew in and there's no corkage (screwage, whatever)- so if you like a cold beer with your chinese cuisine- do it!

and last but not least, the bill for 6 people who lurrve food and have no shame in saying "another one of those, please" was (drum roll please)...75 bones. yes, shanghai house...your cold and aloof waitress, room devoid of personality, spectacular food and more than accommodating prices have won me over...and i'll be back!

excerpts: Just tried for lunch: Had the dumplings, handcut noodles, and vegetarian goose
(Layers of dofu wrapped around mushroom filling).
Everything was fresh and tasty and not greasy - a big plus to me!
Only negative was friendly but slightly slow service - so go for a leisurely, relaxing meal!
Good prices but still cash only.
vegetarian goose.author: Gale H.
vegetarian goose.review: Just tried for lunch: Had the dumplings, handcut noodles, and vegetarian goose (Layers of dofu wrapped around mushroom filling). Everything was fresh and tasty and not greasy - a big plus to me! Only negative was friendly but slightly slow service - so go for a leisurely, relaxing meal! Good prices but still cash only.

excerpts: The vegetarian goose was AWESOME.
It's basically a roll of tofu skin (read:  many layers), with chinese mushrooms inside (shiitake I believe), fried, and then cut up so it kinda looks like goose breast meat.
vegetarian goose.author: Fong L.
vegetarian goose.review:
update:  7/16/07
---
had the classic shanghai "yan du xian" in a stone pot today, and it was awesome.  The broth was white and rich (way better than a tonkotsu broth because of the smokey ham flavor), chinese style ham/cured pork, tofu skin rolled and tied in knots to soak up the broth, and freshly boiled bamboo shoots (definitely not canned), made for a perfect classic soup.  Could have used a vegetable like qing gang cai though, but ah well.

The vegetarian goose was AWESOME.  It's basically a roll of tofu skin (read:  many layers), with chinese mushrooms inside (shiitake I believe), fried, and then cut up so it kinda looks like goose breast meat.  flavor and texture were awesome (except I hate mushrooms, so I picked those out).

The loufa melon with gluten puffs was good--would have been better if they peeled all the skin off the melon to remove the bitterness, but overall it was stir-fried right.  

xiaolongbao has dropped to B-/C+ grade.  They were stuck to the basket, and all of them were popped.  No soup.  Skin was thick, and overall they seemed overcooked.

original review:  4/16/07
---
FINALLY a passable shanghai restaurant in the city.  FINALLY.
Shanghai dumpling king:  mediocre, heavy handed crap.
Old shanghai:  decent food, but not shanghai food.
shanghai noodle house:  decent, but not made with the craftsmanship I'm looking for.

The xiao long bao were mediocre--B grade.  Some soup, and the skin thickness varied from passably thin to way too thick.  Also, the lack of napa cabbage under the dumplings let the dumplings pop because they stuck to the basket.

But the stir fried food themselves... were actually decent.  Only had 3 dishes so far, but they were:
-spinach with tofu "bai ye", like tofu skin but a little thicker with a slightly rougher texture.  THis was stir fried beautifully, and the spinach was nice and clean--no sand.  The chicken broth added just enough flavor, soaked up by the bai ye.

-sweet and sour ribs.  ALMOST perfect.  These were black like they should have been, but weren't sour enough to match the sweetness.  Also the ribs were not fried quiet enough--the ribs weren't falling off the bone, and the bones were not edible.  BUT, they were still tasty, using the right black (zhen jiang) vinegar.  We asked for more vinegar and poured it on top, and then it was sour enough.

-wine sauce fish.  ALMOST perfect.  A little too salty, and needed to be a little bit sweeter.  But otherwise, it was stir fried perfectly, and the black wood ear fungus was very tender and just right.
-salted mustard green (aka snow cabbage, xue cai), edamame (mao dou), pork strand (rou si)  knife-shaved soup noodles (dao xiao tang mian).  On Ed's recommendation, we had to get these knife shaved noodles.  The noodles themselves were the perfect texture and consistency--nice and chewy--though the length and thickness of the noodle could have been better (it's tough to control, and takes a lot of skill to make right, because you shave the noodles directly off of a lump of dough, into the boiling water).  The soup however... had soy sauce in it?!  and was too salty with not enough flavor.  not the tasty, clean, chicken-pork white broth I'm used to for salted mustard green soup noodles.  Still, it was good.  These are all shanghai classic dishes by the way, as we were deliberately testing the chef.

For dessert, they had fermented rice with mochi rice soup balls (filled with sesame paste).  This is a shanghai classic dessert.  The chef added osmanthus flower, as he's supposed to, and just the right amount.  It totally hit the spot.  They also have an "eight treasure rice" (ba bao fan), which is sticky rice (aka sweet rice, mochi rice, or glutinous rice) steamed with 8 "treasures" including lotus seeds, red beans, etc, and honey on top.  But we'll have to order it next time.

with the bill, they brought us half an orange, cut up--as they do in many true chinese restaurants.  no lame-ass fortune cookies here.

I loved it!  I've been forced to lower my shanghai food standards ever since I've come to the city, and this place finally hit the spot.  It's nowhere near best in the bay, but finally, there's a passable shanghai place in the city!

(the large bowl of knife-shaved noodles.. were only 5.75 ea before tax and tip.... my people rule)

excerpts: Faves include potstickers, vegetarian goose, kung pao prawns and anything else we ever order.
This isnt the place to go for proper, timely service and they don't serve alcohol but you can bring your own!
I often bring my own wine and glasses!!
No Corkage fee... and again, the food rocks.
It's like cornstarch never existed and the only types of vegetables were fresh...
vegetarian goose.author: let's c.
vegetarian goose.review: This is the best Chinese food I have ever eaten. It is fresh and flavorful and the textures are bang on. If you want greasy, heavy Chinese, don't come here. I have brought many different people here and they always love it. Faves include potstickers, vegetarian goose, kung pao prawns and anything else we ever order. This isnt the place to go for proper, timely service and they don't serve alcohol but you can bring your own! I often bring my own wine and glasses!! No Corkage fee... and again, the food rocks. It's like cornstarch never existed and the only types of vegetables were fresh...

excerpts:
Sautéed string beans 
Dry fried chicken wings 
Hot and sour soup 
Wonton soup
hot and sour soup.author: Shannon M.
hot and sour soup.review:
Shanghai House is the best place in San Francisco to get affordable XLB. A staple in the outer Richmond. 

This tiny, hole-in-the-wall restaurant is intimate and can get very busy and full in a matter of minutes. It's worth the wait. Don't be offended by the lady - she is a hard working woman and the only server. As a 20 year customer I recommend: 

Green onion pancake 
XLB 
Sautéed string beans 
Dry fried chicken wings 
Hot and sour soup 
Wonton soup 

If you come for lunch, you can't go wrong getting a lunch special.

If you're a wing lover then you'll absolutely LOVE the dried fried chicken wings! 

Closed on Tuesdays like all the OG restaurants 
CASH ONLY

excerpts: The hot and sour soup tasted like vinegar and water, soup dumplings were okay, stir fry beans were salty and drenched in a pool of hot oil.
Saw me spill my tea, stared at me, and didn't even bring me any napkins when I tried asking.
When it came time to pay the check she took forever as well.
Had to go to the counter and pay the bill.
She also told the people waiting in the front that they would have to *points at us* wait for our table.
So rude.
Never again.
hot and sour soup.author: Monica L.
hot and sour soup.review: Went here thinking things would be okay. Def a no no. Worst service ever. The lady who was serving (probably the owner) came to us in the beginning and threw our utensils on the table. She looked like she hated her life. She took forever to come and take our order and when the food came it was a disappointment. The hot and sour soup tasted like vinegar and water, soup dumplings were okay, stir fry beans were salty and drenched in a pool of hot oil. Saw me spill my tea, stared at me, and didn't even bring me any napkins when I tried asking. When it came time to pay the check she took forever as well. Had to go to the counter and pay the bill. She also told the people waiting in the front that they would have to *points at us* wait for our table. So rude. Never again.

excerpts:
- Hot and sour soup is high on the sour note and unbalanced so if one likes a sour and sour soup, this place has a bowl just for you. 
- Fried shanghai dumpling, which is basically the XLB but pan-friend to produce a crispy bottom.
If you've ordered this and the XLB, consider yourself having XLB two-ways.
It's a different texture with the shell being crispy on the bottom but still with nice taste pork filling in the middle.
- Bean curd sheets with soybean, and pickled mustard greens-not great but does its job
, the cook didn't bother to tease out the sheets so the whole thing clumped together making this less appetizing to look and irksome while trying to consume.
- Shanghai noodle tastes more or less like your run of the mill shanghai stir-fried noodle with strips of pork and some soft and mushy noodle with napa cabbage and spinach.
So, the verdict is, if you're around this part of town and have an hankering craving for XLB, Shanghai House is the place for you.
hot and sour soup.author: Taffany H.
hot and sour soup.review:
3.5 Stars. 
It's a smallish restaurant with two front of the house staff but the food is well prepared; so it's an intimate experience. Expect slow service and pay everything in CASH ONLY.

- Dry fried chicken which is fine, large winglets with thick crispy batter but overall this didn't quite hit the home run experience I was searching for.  
- XLB is quite excellent with delicately thin and chewy shell and nicely seasoned and toothsome pork stuffing housed within. 
- Hot and sour soup is high on the sour note and unbalanced so if one likes a sour and sour soup, this place has a bowl just for you. 
- Fried shanghai dumpling, which is basically the XLB but pan-friend to produce a crispy bottom. If you've ordered this and the XLB, consider yourself having XLB two-ways. It's a different texture with the shell being crispy on the bottom but still with nice taste pork filling in the middle. 
- Bean curd sheets with soybean, and pickled mustard greens-not great but does its job, the cook didn't bother to tease out the sheets so the whole thing clumped together making this less appetizing to look and irksome while trying to consume. 
- Shanghai noodle tastes more or less like your run of the mill shanghai stir-fried noodle with strips of pork and some soft and mushy noodle with napa cabbage and spinach.
So, the verdict is, if you're around this part of town and have an hankering craving for XLB, Shanghai House is the place for you.

excerpts: Hot and sour soup tasted like hot vinegar.
hot and sour soup.author: Maple L.
hot and sour soup.review:
If I can give them no stars, I would have. First, the service sucks. I appreciate the fact that they were opened on NYE but if they are so unhappy about their life then don't open. The server threw everything at me and my friend with a bad attitude. If you are not white don't go there. 

Food is bad, except for the soup dumplings. Hot and sour soup tasted like hot vinegar.

excerpts: I order their hot and sour soup, tan tan noodles, house special shanghai stir fried noodles, .
Below average.
I can get better food for a lot less.
No sign in restaurant that said CASH ONLY!
Lucky we had cash with us or else we'll be in the back doing dishes!
hot and sour soup.author: Maggie L.
hot and sour soup.review: I am really disappointed in their food.  Whatever you do... don't go to the bathroom first or else you'll run out so fast!  I visit their restroom after my meal and I was disgusted!  I order their hot and sour soup, tan tan noodles, house special shanghai stir fried noodles, .  Below average. I can get better food for a lot less.  No sign in restaurant that said CASH ONLY!  Lucky we had cash with us or else we'll be in the back doing dishes!

excerpts: Kung pao chicken was good too but super spicy, the hot and sour soup is spot on!!!!!
Definitely coming back!
hot and sour soup.author: Christi M.
hot and sour soup.review: The chicken chow mein here is awesome! The noodles were perfect and the sauce is delicious! Kung pao chicken was good too but super spicy, the hot and sour soup is spot on!!!!!  Definitely coming back!

excerpts:
Hot and Sour Soup
3)
hot and sour soup.author: Allen K.
hot and sour soup.review:
Let me start by saying, and if it's not already obvious, I'm Asian American and more specifically, Chinese American.  I grew up eating very traditional Chinese food BUT at the same time love the taste of "americanized" chinese food like "general's chicken" kung pao, sweet and sour, etc.

This place is suits BOTH palates.  It's a little far from everything but if you have extra time and a car, this place is WORTH IT. Small but pleasant, you will be greeted by a chinese lady who doesn't speak much.  While she may seem unfriendly at first, come back a few more times and she will recognize you and greet you with a smile.  

Here are your MUST ORDERS: 
1) Dried Fried Chicken Wings
2) Hot and Sour Soup
3) Xiao Long Bao (Pork Soup Dumplings)
4) hand cut noodles

The rest is up to you.  This place is CASH ONLY and a very good deal.  With 4-6 people, don't expect to pay more than $15-$20.

excerpts: Started with a hot and sour soup - this was just plain bad.
I've had unremarkable H&S before
but this was outright awful.
Extremely sour with no hot... lack of flavor, odd vegetables, disjointed, and simply wrong.
I had about 3 spoonfuls before putting it aside.
hot and sour soup.author: Austin L.
hot and sour soup.review:
This is my first one-star review... In an effort to maintain credibility I'm going to use the old tried and true Zagat framework to organize my thinking and response.

Decor:  When I first walked in I got a really weird feeling - the restaurant is a small, rectangular, beige-colored room with no decoration whatsoever.  Furthermore, there was no music on and oddly hushed conversation.  I felt like I had made a big mistake by even walking through the door.  Once we'd been seated the front door kept opening ON ITS OWN and letting the cold richmond air blow across my neck.  Not fun.


Food:  Started with a hot and sour soup - this was just plain bad.  I've had unremarkable H&S before but this was outright awful.  Extremely sour with no hot... lack of flavor, odd vegetables, disjointed, and simply wrong.  I had about 3 spoonfuls before putting it aside.  Zha Do Fu - Fried tofu appetizer - this was OK - I mean.. what could go wrong.  Tasted like decently good store-bought tofu that had been fried.  Accompanying sauce was uninteresting.  The main event: xiao long bao - these were only OK - too sweet and the skin was dry and a little crumbly - I've had better.  Main dish: Tofu Noodles with Edamame - this tasted like nothing - funky-ass texture, disgusting presentation, and no flavor.  Epic failure.

Service:  slow, inattentive, and had to be asked for everything.  They even forgot to serve the vinegar with the dumplings.  I raised a hand to ask one of the workers there for it, she saw me, and simply walked back into the kitchen.  How's that for service?

In summary, don't go here.

excerpts: The wonton soup was very disappointing.
Frozen dumplings are never a good thing and the soup was very greasy tasting.
wonton soup.author: J Z.
wonton soup.review:
It has been over 8 years since I last visited the Shanghai House and now I remember why.  The service was and continues to be horrible.  It is slow and unfriendly.  The food was mixed.  The kung pow chicken was good.  The wonton soup was very disappointing. Frozen dumplings are never a good thing and the soup was very greasy tasting.  The broccoli beef was okay - too sweet. 

Not recommended

excerpts: Wonton soup not great.
The meat in the wontons seemed to be "mystery meat.
wonton soup.author: Adam G.
wonton soup.review:
dumplings a bit over-cooked such that skin soft and watery.
Wonton soup not great. The meat in the wontons seemed to be "mystery meat."
Green onion pancakes were very good, but no hot mustard to dip them in ("they were out.")
Combo fried rice had a weird flavor.

Lot's of better Chinese restaurants around. I don't understand why this one is generally very busy with Gringos who come from other areas of SF just for this restaurant.

excerpts: IWe also had the wonton soup and that was good too.
wonton soup.author: kevin l.
wonton soup.review:
If I can give half a star this place would get 3.5 stars.  I should have posted this years ago. I felt like eating some Xiao Long Baos and decided to come to this place since Shanghai Dumpling King had a line out the door.  I'm glad that we decided to on this place because I feel the food to be better. This place is small and had about 10 tables.

FOOD
I really like the food here. The xiao long baos tasted really fresh. I also had green onion pancake and a sweet and savory rice roll. IWe also had the wonton soup and that was good too. Just slightly on the salty side but good none the less. 

SERVICE
Although we were seated pretty quickly the place got packed pretty fast. Service here isn't something I would write home about. It's actually pretty bad but I come for the food.

Similar to most Chinese places I've eaten at, the service could have been a lot better.  Food was good so I'll be back.

excerpts: I ordered green onion pancakes, wonton soup and pork dumplings.
wonton soup.author: Lina P.
wonton soup.review:
I stopped here after reading the newspaper article posted in the window, the title caught my attention: "Shanghai House is worth the wait," and so I waited. 

I ordered green onion pancakes, wonton soup and pork dumplings. I really enjoyed the pancakes and the soup, while the dumpling skin was a bit too thick for me. 

The service was a bit slow, but the wait gave me opportunity to observe other customers, which was nice.

I would definitely recommend the place to my friends and come back for the things recommended by other Yelpers that I didn't get a chance to try yet.

excerpts: Shanghai dumplings, pot stickers, wonton soup, all amazing.
wonton soup.author: Heather L.
wonton soup.review: Shanghai dumplings, pot stickers, wonton soup, all amazing.  Mongolian beef was soooooo spicy, but also very good.  It's BYOB - which is cool.  However, service I incredibly slow and fairly unfriendly - however according to my Chinese dining mate, he wouldn't expect it any other way.

excerpts: The wonton soup was also bland with no flavor.
I probably won't go back here unless it's the only thing open.
wonton soup.author: Katherine F.
wonton soup.review:
Good location in front of the theater, but definitely not as good as Shanghai Dumpling King. The chicken was also old, so it tasted not so great inside. The initial flavoring on the outside of the Santung wannabe wings was decent, but it didn't soak into the old "freezer burned" chicken. The wonton soup was also bland with no flavor. I probably won't go back here unless it's the only thing open. They also forgot our rice, but I canceled it. 

The only reason why I'm giving this place a 2 star is because the service was ok and the xiao long baos had a lot of soup in it, although they were small. 

Please note to all the people who use the 7x7 list for reference on what to eat in the city...RESTAURANTS PAY TO BE ON THAT LIST...it's not because they are necessarily the best.

No credit cards here either.

excerpts: i think it's overrated for this), the knife cut noodle in wonton soup  (I was really impressed with how hot they kept the bowl of soup and the bowl itself - love my soup burning scalding hot!), and the ham bamboo beancurd casserole soup (also really good, wish there was more vegetable and bamboo) but the soup was really good.
Overall, a good place - prob has other dishes that are amazing.
Want to try the ribs, wings, noodles next time!
wonton soup.author: Jamie T.
wonton soup.review: Long lines from being in SF 7x7. I was waiting across the street to try out Purple Kow when I saw people form lines outside. I walked over to see if I could place my name on a waiting list only to find that they don't operate by lists. You've got to physically be waiting in line - they also angered this man in front of me by serving takeout to the lady behind him before him. Hard to say because you have to serve takeout since she wasn't waiting for a table...but understand where he's coming from - they had a ton of miscommunication. She seated us (table of 2) in the inner most table over the table of 3 (angry man) which caused him to give me angry stares from outside the window. Then he was seated next to us. Awkward. Either way, you're supposed to reserve the pig knuckle one day ahead but since this was a spontaneous dinner, we weren't able to try that. We ordered the XLB (didn't taste the meat - i think it's overrated for this), the knife cut noodle in wonton soup  (I was really impressed with how hot they kept the bowl of soup and the bowl itself - love my soup burning scalding hot!), and the ham bamboo beancurd casserole soup (also really good, wish there was more vegetable and bamboo) but the soup was really good. Overall, a good place - prob has other dishes that are amazing. Want to try the ribs, wings, noodles next time!

excerpts: and I ordered wonton mein and my ordered a regular wonton soup.
The baby shanghai dumplings were like little pockets of bursting flavor and broth.
The first bite i took , i was like whoa
and then the broth dripped out.
lols
i was like eh O_o
The noodles were hand made, the texture, taste and firmness of the homemade noodles were dead set perfect.
I love eating noodles with my soup.
I could eat noodles for breakfast, lunch and dinner and even as a snack.
My only complaint was that there should have been more wontons for the price we paid.
I will return and try more of the dumplings.
wonton soup.author: Jonathan W.
wonton soup.review: 3.5 stars for me. I had forgotten to bring my lunch to work that day and I work very close by to this place. I called my buddy up and we decided to come here because we were in the mood for noodles and soup but more importantly I wanted to check out the dumplings :). We ordered the baby shanghai dumplings and I ordered wonton mein and my ordered a regular wonton soup.  The baby shanghai dumplings were like little pockets of bursting flavor and broth. The first bite i took , i was like whoa and then the broth dripped out. lols i was like eh O_o The noodles were hand made, the texture, taste and firmness of the homemade noodles were dead set perfect. I love eating noodles with my soup. I could eat noodles for breakfast, lunch and dinner and even as a snack. My only complaint was that there should have been more wontons for the price we paid.  I will return and try more of the dumplings.

excerpts: Won ton soup and combo chow mein were meh.
combo chow mein.author: M F.
combo chow mein.review:
Highly recommend if you have 2-3 hours to spare waiting for your food to come out.

Seated ourselves.
Grabbed our own menus.
Waaaaaited for our order to be taken.
Waaaaaaaaaaited for dishes to come.
Dishes came One. At. A. Time. (Rice was last.)
Gave up waiting for 2 dishes.

During this, 2 separate customers got pissed off waiting over an hour for their takeouts; a lot of yelling in the kitchen was heard; 3 tables got frustrated waiting for their tabs/change; and the RBF waitress only lit up when we went to her to pay our tab.

Salt & pepper spare ribs & spicy green beans were good. Won ton soup and combo chow mein were meh. Never got the dumplings.

Towards the end we sat laughing because it felt like a Seinfeld Soup Nazi experience.

You come to be punished.

excerpts: Ordered kung pao chicken, combo chow mein, and some shanghai soup dumplings (xiao long bao).
combo chow mein.author: Kevin B.
combo chow mein.review:
Went here with my wife after catching a movie at the Balboa Twin across the street.  Got takeout since it was about 9pm and they were closing at 9:30pm.  Ordered kung pao chicken, combo chow mein, and some shanghai soup dumplings (xiao long bao).

The food didn't taste that great...and tasted even worse coming up.  I was up all night with food poisoning vomiting.  The kung pao was one of the worst I've ever had, and the filling on the soup dumplings was all mushy.  Threw all the leftovers away immediately in the morning.

Needless to say, we won't be going back...

excerpts:
Regarding Shanghai House on 3641 Balboa Street (Outer Richmond District in S.F., CA):

First off, the ingredients in the Seafood Chow Mein, are not listed in the menu.
seafood chow mein.author: Carol J.
seafood chow mein.review:
Regarding Shanghai House on 3641 Balboa Street (Outer Richmond District in S.F., CA):

First off, the ingredients in the Seafood Chow Mein, are not listed in the menu. On top of that, I went over it with the waitress twice, even repeating what she said once... She told me that it consists of prawns, scallops and oysters. She failed to mention squid - which I loathe! And, to make the mess (as I think of it) - even worse - the noodles or Chow Mein portion of it was so plentiful - it was packed in the small/medium box like dirt hard-packed! So, long story - short, a ton of starchy noodles, pan-pried, about two prawns, one oyster, a shriveled scallop or two and a long repulsive piece of squid.

excerpts: The chicken chow mein here is awesome!
The noodles were perfect and the sauce is delicious!
chicken chow mein.author: Christi M.
chicken chow mein.review: The chicken chow mein here is awesome! The noodles were perfect and the sauce is delicious! Kung pao chicken was good too but super spicy, the hot and sour soup is spot on!!!!!  Definitely coming back!

excerpts: We had Garlic Chicken which was real good and Mogolian beef which was actuall good and Veggie fried rice which was not oily.
Everything was really good.
The Place is small
but I always like that about a restaurant.
The customers were very Diversed which I also like.
The waitress was nice.
We will deifenlty go back there more often.
We will need to get there a bit earlyer
so we can look at the menu better.
I think this is the best spot we have near our house for chinese food.
We ordered 3 items and only spent like 23 bucks which is cool.
Yeah!!!!!
veggie fried rice.author: Ge I.
veggie fried rice.review: We went to this place yesturday night for Dinner. It was almost 9:30pm, that's when they close but they sat us down. The tables were really nice. looks very expensive. The menu is also big. They gave us two menu. They have Dim Sum not allot but good amount. We had Garlic Chicken which was real good and Mogolian beef which was actuall good and Veggie fried rice which was not oily. Everything was really good. The Place is small but I always like that about a restaurant. The customers were very Diversed which I also like. The waitress was nice. We will deifenlty go back there more often. We will need to get there a bit earlyer so we can look at the menu better. I think this is the best spot we have near our house for chinese food. We ordered 3 items and only spent like 23 bucks which is cool. Yeah!!!!!

excerpts:
Combo fried rice
Burnt!
The whole dish tasted burnt.
I know sometimes a little smokiness can be good, but not in fried rice and not to this degree!
The cook should have known not to serve this.
I'm surprised they gave it to us to take home.
Probably hoping we wouldn't complain which we didn't
combo fried rice.author: Elena N.
combo fried rice.review:
I was craving Xiao long bao and Dry fried chicken wings. I've had Shanghai house bookmarked for some time, so instead of trekking across the park into the Sunset to get my fix, I thought I'd finally check Shanghai house off my list. I called in the take out order and the roommate picked it up about 30 mins later.

Dry chicken wings - chicken wings deep fried in batter with garlic, ginger and roast red peppers
A little sweeter than I prefer. The roommate said it was cuz they use honey instead of corn syrup. Though honey is probably better for you, I prefer a different sweetener as the honey overpowered the savory aspect of the dish.

Xiao long bao
These were delish! The skin held up well in the take out container. None of them burst so they all kept their juicy goodness. I liked the thickness of the wrapper and the consistency of the filling.

Potstickers - pork and veggies
Meh! Average potstickers. Nothing to write home about.

Dry sauteed string beans - fresh green beans flash fried and tossed in a garlicky sauce with Chinese pickle
These did not taste dry fried at all! Almost like blanched strings beans mixed in sauce. So bland! They got better the next day but then they got mushy.

House special eggplant - shrimp, chicken and fresh basil
The roommate's pick since he wanted something healthier. I actually liked this dish. Had great flavor and the eggplant was cooked nicely.

Combo fried rice
Burnt! The whole dish tasted burnt. I know sometimes a little smokiness can be good, but not in fried rice and not to this degree! The cook should have known not to serve this. I'm surprised they gave it to us to take home. Probably hoping we wouldn't complain which we didn't so I guess they scored there.

I might come back just for the Xiao long bao, but with Shanghai dumpling king just down the street with better offerings in terms additional dishes, I'll probably skip Shanghai house. No one should be serving burnt rice!

excerpts:
Green onion pancakes were very good, but no hot mustard to dip them in ("they were out.")
Combo fried rice had a weird flavor.
combo fried rice.author: Adam G.
combo fried rice.review:
dumplings a bit over-cooked such that skin soft and watery.
Wonton soup not great. The meat in the wontons seemed to be "mystery meat."
Green onion pancakes were very good, but no hot mustard to dip them in ("they were out.")
Combo fried rice had a weird flavor.

Lot's of better Chinese restaurants around. I don't understand why this one is generally very busy with Gringos who come from other areas of SF just for this restaurant.

excerpts: I thoroughly enjoyed my shrimp fried rice.

The food is piping hot when served 
The only thing that lacks this place is a toilet
shrimp fried rice.author: Aerodaan ..
shrimp fried rice.review:
Don't go for the hospitality. Indeed you need to have a little bit of patience being served but it is worth the wait. Excellent quality of food for a reasonable price. I thoroughly enjoyed my shrimp fried rice. The food is piping hot when served 
The only thing that lacks this place is a toilet

excerpts: Our shrimp fried rice had a weird burnt taste although the shrimp itself was plump and tender.
shrimp fried rice.author: Janice C.
shrimp fried rice.review:
Brusque and slow service combined with ordinary food, I don't think I'll be back here anytime soon.   

You know I'm here for a reason and it's to check off an item on my Big Eat SF list:

#13 soup dumplings at Shanghai House. 

10 pieces of hot Xiao Long Bao brought out in a bamboo steamer.  The soft texture of the steamed wrapping paper, well-seasoned pork, and tasty soup in these one-bite dumplings make you thankful that these only cost $5.50.  (which would cost you $10 at Yank Sing)  

The other items we ordered were okay,  a little too heavy on the oyster sauce on our stir-fry Buddha's Delight which has broccoli, fried tofu, bok choy and carrots.   Our shrimp fried rice had a weird burnt taste although the shrimp itself was plump and tender.   The walnut prawns? a skip. 

This place is small but can probably accommodate around 30 people.  Be prepared to wait if they get busy.  

BTW, cash only.

excerpts: We ordered: 2 orders pot stickers (tiny bite size), Shanghai pan friend noodles, Shanghai sliced rice sticks, bean curd wrapped w/mushrooms, and shrimp fried rice.
shrimp fried rice.author: Rich W.
shrimp fried rice.review:
Shanghai House - weird experience

We ordered: 2 orders pot stickers (tiny bite size), Shanghai pan friend noodles, Shanghai sliced rice sticks, bean curd wrapped w/mushrooms, and shrimp fried rice.

Service was OK, waitress a bit cold.  Dragon lady type.  The Shanghai noodles & rice sticks (very salty).  The fried rice (sliced carrots, mushrooms,  & cabbage)  Is this Shanghai style?  Bizarre...

The pot stickers were tasty (TINY), the bean curd was very good.  CA$H only!  I prefer Shanghai Dumpling King best so far - need to try Old Shanghai next.

excerpts: 2nd my shrimp fried rice had exactly 4 shrimp and 95pecent vegi.
Every bite i had more vegi than rice.
and 3rd noodle soup had sat out to long before bringing it to us which cause the noodles to obsorb all the soup.
Overall this place is very nice visually and service is great, but food isn't great unless you like no flavor and unbalance dishes.
shrimp fried rice.author: David M.
shrimp fried rice.review: The food here was flavorless and oddly portioned. My friends and I decided to try this place out and order acouple things to share and to experiment. 1st soy milk shouldn't taste like water. 2nd my shrimp fried rice had exactly 4 shrimp and 95pecent vegi. Every bite i had more vegi than rice. and 3rd noodle soup had sat out to long before bringing it to us which cause the noodles to obsorb all the soup. Overall this place is very nice visually and service is great, but food isn't great unless you like no flavor and unbalance dishes.

excerpts: and I also had seafood fried rice.
I have to say that the fried rice was rather bland.
The green onion panckaes were crispy, but again, it was bland.
Even the tea itself was watered down.
So sad.
HOWEVER, what was good was the CUTTLEFISH.
Suprisingly, it was GOOD
seafood fried rice.author: Daisy S.
seafood fried rice.review:
I went here for work lunch as recommended by one of my co-workers. It's a pretty new resturant- about 6 months or so, which is kind of small, but cute. It's a pretty clean place, but the service was SLOW. 

The food, I would say are average, but they are pretty decent in prices. I ordered Shanghai dumplings and it was okay, and I also had seafood fried rice. I have to say that the fried rice was rather bland. The green onion panckaes were crispy, but again, it was bland. Even the tea itself was watered down. So sad. HOWEVER, what was good was the CUTTLEFISH. Suprisingly, it was GOOD and that was the only highlight of my lunch. 

I saw that they have dim sum, too. So, maybe next time IF I come around the place again, I would try them. But, I won't make special trip to the place although they have good cuttlefish. I rather go down to Chinatown to eat good chinese food although the place isn't that clean, but it's Chinatown!.

excerpts: I asked for chicken fried rice.
The plate came back with maybe a couple spoonful of rice and topped with so much veggies
and I'm talking about tablespoon size.
I'd say about 10% was rice 15% chicken and 75% veggies.
Server forgot my drink and she looked like a total mess apron was full of stains hands
were greasy when she gave me my drink, food that I received was nasty.
I'm sorry but this place is not good at all from my experience.
chicken fried rice.author: Kevin B.
chicken fried rice.review: I will never come back to this place!! Ate here once when it wasn't busy I asked for chicken fried rice. The plate came back with maybe a couple spoonful of rice and topped with so much veggies and I'm talking about tablespoon size. I'd say about 10% was rice 15% chicken and 75% veggies. Server forgot my drink and she looked like a total mess apron was full of stains hands were greasy when she gave me my drink, food that I received was nasty. I'm sorry but this place is not good at all from my experience.

excerpts: We always order dry fried chicken wings, chicken fried rice with no eggs (i'm allergic) and the vegetarian spring rolls.
I love it with our favorite boba place across the street.
It is a small place if you choose to dine in, but if you can try the food during the lunch specials m-f 11-3, its worth it.
Best $7-$9 you'll spend per person!
chicken fried rice.author: Oluyemi O.
chicken fried rice.review: Me and my boyfriend come here all the time!! Yes it's one server that works really hard and does have the same expression, but she always knows my order and i feel we have a rapport. We always order dry fried chicken wings, chicken fried rice with no eggs (i'm allergic) and the vegetarian spring rolls. I love it with our favorite boba place across the street. It is a small place if you choose to dine in, but if you can try the food during the lunch specials m-f 11-3, its worth it. Best $7-$9 you'll spend per person!

excerpts: Ordered kung pao chicken, combo chow mein, and some shanghai soup dumplings (xiao long bao).
kung pao chicken.author: Kevin B.
kung pao chicken.review:
Went here with my wife after catching a movie at the Balboa Twin across the street.  Got takeout since it was about 9pm and they were closing at 9:30pm.  Ordered kung pao chicken, combo chow mein, and some shanghai soup dumplings (xiao long bao).

The food didn't taste that great...and tasted even worse coming up.  I was up all night with food poisoning vomiting.  The kung pao was one of the worst I've ever had, and the filling on the soup dumplings was all mushy.  Threw all the leftovers away immediately in the morning.

Needless to say, we won't be going back...

excerpts: Kung pao chicken was good too but super spicy, the hot and sour soup is spot on!!!!!
Definitely coming back!
kung pao chicken.author: Christi M.
kung pao chicken.review: The chicken chow mein here is awesome! The noodles were perfect and the sauce is delicious! Kung pao chicken was good too but super spicy, the hot and sour soup is spot on!!!!!  Definitely coming back!

excerpts: The Mongolian Beef and the Kung Pao Chicken was pretty good.
The Kung Pao was definitely spicier than the Mongolian Beef however and the peanuts compliments it very very well.
The Mongolian Beef was nice and tender, but I had preferred it to be just as spicy or spicier than the Kung Pao.
kung pao chicken.author: Killah K.
kung pao chicken.review:
A quaint and cozy place that delivers relatively good food at reasonable prices. The owner and the Chef themselves are actually Shanghai-nese (I myself come from Shanghai, China) so that brought my expectations even higher. 

The first thing I ordered was the Shanghai pork dumplings. You can't come to a Shanghai-nese restaurant without first trying the dumplings. The dumplings were Good. Juices were flowing inside the skin and the skin itself was not hard - which tells you that they are using the right kind of skin. The meatball inside was also cooked perfectly. So for the dumplings, it has my vote. ::thumbs up:: 

I then ordered the Sour and spicy soup - which to my surprise was kind of disappointing. Way too sour for my taste and not spicy at all. Unbalanced and very one-sided. The amount of veggies included in the soup was pretty good, but I couldnt taste any of it due to the overwhelming sour-ness. There was also a slight bitterness that I didn't like. Maybe they derived from the traditional way of making this soup in order to make it more original? I do not know. 

Following the soup I ordered Fried Tofu. Very nice. Was not deep fried like the other Fried Tofu's out there. The fried skin is very thin - covering the tofu just barely. The tofu was also soft - not firm which is the right way to make fried tofu. This I give my ::thumbs up:: 

The Mongolian Beef and the Kung Pao Chicken was pretty good. The Kung Pao was definitely spicier than the Mongolian Beef however and the peanuts compliments it very very well. The Mongolian Beef was nice and tender, but I had preferred it to be just as spicy or spicier than the Kung Pao. 

Overall, the experience was a good one. The service was okay considering that there's only one waiter there. It would've been nice if they had accepted major credit cards, but I guess it is to keep costs low. A little inconvenient, but bearable. Bank of America is literally a block away on the corner. 


Bottom Line: More or less authentic with some deviation from traditional depending what you get. Overall good experience. It was good, but not fantastic. I do support local businesses so I would go here again.

excerpts: Well, the first thing I tried, I ate four or five times before I moved on to anything else and that was the Kung Pao chicken.

I tried only that partly because I liked it so much, partly because I got it at least 4 times to go--you can't order from the "Shanghai" menu on take out orders--and partly because if you order two orders + rice for two you can feed 4 people (take out) for $20!
And that's eating really stand-out Kung Pao--smoky peppers and smoked tofu, lots of veggies (mostly zucchini
but it's good here) and tasty chicken.
kung pao chicken.author: Liza B.
kung pao chicken.review:
Why anyone would rate this great little place less than 4 stars is a mystery to me--perhaps they ordered the wrong things or maybe they came from outside this neighborhood...Yes I guess if I bussed, biked or drove over here from the Mission, I would probably not give it 5 stars, but this yummy, inexpensive restaurant is in MY neighborhood where good restaurants are far outnumbered by really, really dismal ones. 

My first favorite restaurant in this stretch has always been Miki's right next door...but now I have TWO new favorites on Balboa. Yu Zen and Shanghai House. 

What did I eat there that made me this excited? Well, the first thing I tried, I ate four or five times before I moved on to anything else and that was the Kung Pao chicken. I tried only that partly because I liked it so much, partly because I got it at least 4 times to go--you can't order from the "Shanghai" menu on take out orders--and partly because if you order two orders + rice for two you can feed 4 people (take out) for $20! And that's eating really stand-out Kung Pao--smoky peppers and smoked tofu, lots of veggies (mostly zucchini but it's good here) and tasty chicken. Just right. 

My interest in Chinese Food in my neighborhood (exception of all exceptions: Ton Kiang for brunch) has seriously waned ~ it seemed every time I went for Chinese the last  few years I ate something that was too greasy, too sweet or just not memorable. 

Talk about memorable! the Shanghai style Vegetable Soup with hand cut noodles I had here last weekend has been stuck in my savory, sensory memory ever since and I just can't shake it. Out of all three dishes I ate that meal (my friend and I were hungry and determined to sample more of the menu) the said soup was actually the least "exciting" dish,  but for some reason it's the one that won out as top memorable sense that I can still "taste". I was actually most "excited" about the Bok Choy with Wheat Gluten Dumplings. This was amazingly good and yummy with a delicious sauce soaking the dumplings and the perfectly sized baby bok choy (you don't have to make a slippery slimy fool of yourself with these as you do with typically sized bok choy). Plus I am a sucker for really yummy "meat alternatives". 

And then to show that I am also a sucker for some meats, I also highly recommend the Tea Smoked Duck. It's so delicious! and for someone like me who doesn't eat meat other than poultry or fish, Duck prepared like this is as tasty and decadent as any pork dish might be (read: fatty and delicious and crispy).

So yes, you should try this place. But make sure you look at the Shanghai Menu. it's a mysterious practice they have of only giving it to you with the other menu (straight american chinese food?)--so some people may never even see it (esp. if you order take out)

update: since this review I've tried a few other notable dishes: the Vegetarian Goose (with shitake mushrooms) is delicious as are the Vegetarian Steamed Dumplings. The Mu Shu Vegetables were just right, too. The Vegetable Soup with hand-cut noodles wasn't as exciting as the first time I had it, but that happens sometimes ; ) Obviously plenty for a vegetarian to eat, although I'm not vegetairian. 

update #2: Now that I eat all meat, I can rate the Shanghai pork dumplings too--more delicate and nicer than the (notorious) ones up the street. And the Golden Prawns are my new favorite dish! Yum Yum

update #3: for some reason, after all of these years, I had never ordered the chicken wings until sometime the end of this last year. Oh my! Now it's the new 'must have' --hot, spicy, sweet, crunchy--it's a meal and dessert all at once. Leftovers that we have been known to fight over the next day ("hey you took two pieces!") Chicken crack.

excerpts: They have one menu of standard chinese fare but done better than any place I have tried; kung pao chicken, twice cooked pork etc.
And one menu of more esoteric dishes that they probably wont give you unless you are asian or if you ask for it.
The second menu has sizzling clay pot rice, pork belly, pork knuckle...
Be sure and check this place out
kung pao chicken.author: Vincent C.
kung pao chicken.review:
I would just give this five stars if it was only based on the food.  The service is simply lacking...sloooowwww.
That being said, the food is some of the best chinese I have had.  If you dine in be sure and ask for both menus.  They have one menu of standard chinese fare but done better than any place I have tried; kung pao chicken, twice cooked pork etc. And one menu of more esoteric dishes that they probably wont give you unless you are asian or if you ask for it.  The second menu has sizzling clay pot rice, pork belly, pork knuckle...
Be sure and check this place out

excerpts: The last thing we ordered was the dry fried chicken wings
(I have a picture of this).
Omg, TERRIBLE.
The batter was waaaaaay too thick to the point I wasn't sure if I was eating the chicken or the batter.
And the sauce was...
well, there was no sauce actually; instead, they're just soaked in chili oil!
Yes!!!
They fried the wings and probably decided they were not oily enough
so they drenched the wings in a pool of chili oil.
OMG!
dry fried chicken wings.author: Kev H.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Zero star!  That's what this review should give, but Yelp is too generous and sets one star as the lowest rate.  But they really deserve zero star, and I'll tell you why.

Service:
How do I put this... the lady just didn't give a sh*t.  My friends and I arrived, sat down, and then lady just came to our table and literally slap the menu on our table.  After the food came, as we were eating, we noticed that the lady was on her phone the whole dang time at the cash register table, MEANWHILE approximately three tables were still full of dirty dishes left by the guests that had already gone for almost 20 mins!!!  I mean, come freakin on.  We were trying to eat here!  So at least you could try to keep the restaurant clean and tidy.  And it wasn't like you had other things to do!  And after we had our food, we had to ask for the check three times, yes THREE TIMES, before she finally brought it to us.  Uhhh, gurl, I know you hate your job, but we needed to get outta there.

Food:
Greasy greasy greasy.  I had 4 things actually.  3 didn't come looking appetizing so my asian instinct to take pictures of them just didn't kick in.  They were beef tripes in chili oil, pork and leek dumplings, and mushy pork.  Flavor was ok, but I could tell all the dishes were just low quality cooking.  Sorry but it's true.  The last thing we ordered was the dry fried chicken wings (I have a picture of this).  Omg, TERRIBLE.  The batter was waaaaaay too thick to the point I wasn't sure if I was eating the chicken or the batter.  And the sauce was...well, there was no sauce actually; instead, they're just soaked in chili oil!  Yes!!!  They fried the wings and probably decided they were not oily enough so they drenched the wings in a pool of chili oil.  OMG!  Nooooooooooooo..........

Rating:
It should really be zero star.  Oh, and it's a cash only place.

excerpts: Dry fried chicken wings (did not see item on menu) - definitely a disappointment.
The basil on top was black and in a clump, which did not look appetizing.
The outside was way too hard and crunchy with a thick layer of batter.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Nicole M.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
No wait on a Sunday around noon, though there were a lot of people coming in and out and ordering items to go. First let's talk food.

Shanghai steamed baby dumplings ($8.50) - aka XLB, comes with 10. This was made very well - the skin was nice and thin but strong enough to be transferred onto my spoon without breaking and letting the soup escape. The meat was soft and moist and the soup was great. I found a hair in one of them (ew, but this happens often enough in Chinese restaurants that I'm not even that fazed anymore), and the waitress apologized and quickly brought us a new batch.
Shanghai pan fried dumplings ($11.95) - comes with 8. This came out looking delicious with nicely browned bottoms. The outside was slightly crispy and the meat inside was soft and juicy. Done really well and in a great size, too!
Savory rice roll ($4.25) - perhaps the smallest rice roll I have ever been served at a restaurant. This meant that there wasn't so much filling, although the actual ratio of filling to rice was good. I personally would have preferred more pork floss inside, but it still tasted good. Only problem was the portion.
Cucumber & bean thread sheet ($9.95) - not bad but expensive for $10. I would have liked less peanut sauce. I took a bite of the leftovers the very next day, and it had a terrible mushy consistency, so definitely finish this the day of if you're going to order it.
Dry fried chicken wings (did not see item on menu) - definitely a disappointment. The basil on top was black and in a clump, which did not look appetizing. The outside was way too hard and crunchy with a thick layer of batter. The sauce itself was decent, but doesn't even hold a candle to San Tung.

Service was not good. When we were waiting to order, the lady was just standing behind the counter, where there is a big plant in the way. Not sure if she just couldn't see us or was taking a break, but I saw a customer from another table walk up to put in her order because she had been waiting for a while already. That same lady at the counter yelled into the kitchen so loudly once that a little girl sitting a few tables over said, "It's so loud!" hahaha. Two of our items came out separately with the servers not knowing which table they were for - there aren't that many tables in there! When they were confused and looking around, we had to tell them that the dishes were ours. When the waitress took away my soup spoon with the hair in the dumpling, she didn't give me a new spoon until I asked. And finally, we sat next to the door and it didn't close properly so the draft was blowing at us each time someone walked in or out. I am fully aware that some of these things are nitpicky, but when combined with hair in my dumpling, subpar service, and only okay food, this makes for an overall unsatisfactory meal that deserves a rating of "Meh. I've experienced better."

Also, what's with using saucers as plates??

excerpts: We ordered their xiao long baos and their dry fried chicken wings.
The wings are HUGE, but you can definitely tell that most of it is the breading.
The sauce is good and similar to the one at San Tung's, but not quite.
The xiao long baos though
... they were probably the best ones I've had in the area!
dry fried chicken wings.author: Sydney C.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Only reason this place is getting a 4 stars is for the food. The service, on the other hand, could be better. For such a small restaurant, I felt like it was so difficult to get the attention of anyone. Once you walk in, you're seated almost immediately, but after that, it's like they completely forget about you. The workers are completely unaware of their surroundings and don't check up on their customers often enough. 

We ordered their xiao long baos and their dry fried chicken wings. The wings are HUGE, but you can definitely tell that most of it is the breading. The sauce is good and similar to the one at San Tung's, but not quite. The xiao long baos though... they were probably the best ones I've had in the area! They were perfect.

It's funny how we ended up here. We were supposed to try out Shanghai Dumpling King a block down, but we accidentally went in here, and when we realized it, it was too late, they already served us tea/water, lol! But I'm glad we stayed. 

I would definitely come again. Hopefully their service improves! It's cash only btw.

excerpts: We waited 1 hour for the dry fried chicken wings, the lady who waited on us had no expression on her face, and she was on her phone when we tried to flag her down.
The food on the other hand was pretty good.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Charles S.
dry fried chicken wings.review: Just like what most other reviewers said, the service is horrible. We waited 1 hour for the dry fried chicken wings, the lady who waited on us had no expression on her face, and she was on her phone when we tried to flag her down. The food on the other hand was pretty good. Would definitely recommend the green onion pancakes, Xiao Long Baos, and the dry fried chicken. The shanghai pan fried noodles were below average. Overall, if you came here for the dry fried chicken, just stick to san tungs.

excerpts:
Sautéed string beans 
Dry fried chicken wings 
Hot and sour soup 
Wonton soup
dry fried chicken wings.author: Shannon M.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Shanghai House is the best place in San Francisco to get affordable XLB. A staple in the outer Richmond. 

This tiny, hole-in-the-wall restaurant is intimate and can get very busy and full in a matter of minutes. It's worth the wait. Don't be offended by the lady - she is a hard working woman and the only server. As a 20 year customer I recommend: 

Green onion pancake 
XLB 
Sautéed string beans 
Dry fried chicken wings 
Hot and sour soup 
Wonton soup 

If you come for lunch, you can't go wrong getting a lunch special.

If you're a wing lover then you'll absolutely LOVE the dried fried chicken wings! 

Closed on Tuesdays like all the OG restaurants 
CASH ONLY

excerpts: I ordered the dry fried chicken wings and the pork dumplings.
She shuffled to the kitchen with my order.
The dry fried chicken wings and pork dumplings (xiao long bao) were great.
The chicken was coated in a spicy honey glaze that crystallized the chicken skin into a heavenly, decadent candy shell that stayed crisp even when reheated and eaten the next day.
The dumplings were fresh, tasty and juicy.
The tender skin encapsulated a delicious broth that pleased the senses.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Linda H.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Immediately upon walking into the restaurant, I could see why this place was rated so poorly.  There was a grim and uninviting air to the place that was difficult to ignore.  The waitress was not rude but, instead, had a haggard, defeated demeanor that screamed "life sucks and so do you."   She shuffled slowly from customer to customer, looking as if she would rather be anywhere than where she was and not seeming to care whether a customer was happy or sad, pleased or displeased.  I can't explain the service better than that but it did subconsciously dampen the pleasure of the experience. 

I helped myself to a menu and looked it over, confused as to why none of the items that other Yelpers raved about were not on the menu.  The waitress saw me looking back and forth in confusion between the Yelp review on my cellphone and the menu in my hand and simply said "two menus" as she handed me a different menu that I had not noticed before.  

I ordered the dry fried chicken wings and the pork dumplings.   She shuffled to the kitchen with my order.  A gloomy, dark cloud loomed over her head, making Eeyore's look like rainbows and sunshine.   

Getting the food took awhile but was definitely worth the wait.   The meal came out piping hot so I'm certain that the delay was just the cooking time and was no fault of the waitress.  

The dry fried chicken wings and pork dumplings (xiao long bao) were great.  The chicken was coated in a spicy honey glaze that crystallized the chicken skin into a heavenly, decadent candy shell that stayed crisp even when reheated and eaten the next day.  The dumplings were fresh, tasty and juicy.  The tender skin encapsulated a delicious broth that pleased the senses.  So delicious!Compliments to the chef! 

Given how delicious the food was, I can NOT give this restaurant any lower than a 4 star rating despite the bad vibe.  I highly recommend trying the dumplings and the chicken TO GO so that you can truly enjoy the meal!   And please, be kind to the waitress.  I don't know what caused the doom and gloom but let's just pretend we're Care Bears here and spread the love to someone in need.

excerpts:
- Dry fried chicken wings: fantastic sauce, wanted to put it on everything else
- Mu-shu pork: great dish to share
- Hand cut noodles: my favorite dish - incredible noodles!
dry fried chicken wings.author: Regina L.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Don't get me wrong, the food at Shanghai House is exceptional and I do feel bad giving a three star review, but everything else about the experience is mediocre at best. 

Let's start with the positives: arrived on a Friday evening around 7 with four friends and got sat immediately. We ordered a ton of food and EVERYTHING was fantastic. Service was pretty quick and the server was pretty responsive. Highlights include:
- Green onion pancakes: great texture and not too greasy
- Shanghai dumplings: honestly some of the best dumplings I've ever had - so juicy!
- Dry fried chicken wings: fantastic sauce, wanted to put it on everything else
- Mu-shu pork: great dish to share
- Hand cut noodles: my favorite dish - incredible noodles!

The not-so-great:
- We realized that we were given two completely different menus, so make sure that you get both menus to ensure you're seeing all of your options
- Cash only! Normally not a problem when I'm just picking up something for myself but for a large group it's a bit of a hassle
- Staff relatively unfriendly/aloof
- State of dining area could certainly use some upgrades/deep cleaning. Don't even get me STARTED on the state of their bathroom.
- Pretty far out there in the Richmond; it's definitely a trek to get over there from the other side of town

All in all, super glad I got to experience their food, but there are a ton of good places in the Chinatown area that would hit the spot and save me a ton of travel time.

excerpts: The dry fried chicken wings were amazing, probably the best I have ever had.
Pan fried buns had a nice crispy exterior but just a pork meatball inside.
A veggie version would have been better for me.
Staff were great and prices were OK.
Make sure you make the trek to the bathroom, as it takes you though the kitchen so you can see the chef at work.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Jeremy R.
dry fried chicken wings.review: Following the advice of Yelp legend, Tian Q., I sought out Shanghai House for my Xaio Long Bao fix. In spite of a stupid parking ticket, I still enjoyed my lunch. The XLB were not as good as Din Tai Fung but satisfying nonetheless. The dry fried chicken wings were amazing, probably the best I have ever had. Pan fried buns had a nice crispy exterior but just a pork meatball inside. A veggie version would have been better for me. Staff were great and prices were OK. Make sure you make the trek to the bathroom, as it takes you though the kitchen so you can see the chef at work.

excerpts: *Dry fried chicken wings (5/5)
My boyfriend
and I had quite a debate over this for years on whose chicken wing reigned supreme.
He eventually won me over after the last time I went to San Tung
the wings were a little overdone.
SUPER SWEET and is amazing over rice.
Pet peeve of mine is when wings have no meat on them.
This place has HUGE wings and the crispy skin wins my heart every time.
It is a bit tricky to eat but my boyfriend still loves me so long hair don't care.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Rosie E.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Short Version: Bigger better dried fried chicken wings than San Tung. Enough Said. 
**CASH ONLY**

***Food***
*Dry fried chicken wings (5/5)
My boyfriend and I had quite a debate over this for years on whose chicken wing reigned supreme. He eventually won me over after the last time I went to San Tung the wings were a little overdone. SUPER SWEET and is amazing over rice. Pet peeve of mine is when wings have no meat on them. This place has HUGE wings and the crispy skin wins my heart every time. It is a bit tricky to eat but my boyfriend still loves me so long hair don't care. If you are ordering for a large table I suggest getting 2 orders.

*Dry sautéed green beans w/shrimp (5/5)
We usually just order it as-is w/o adding meat/shrimp but we felt fancy I guess that day. DELISH. Green beans were perfectly crunchy and snappy(?). Will be adding to our normal repertoire.

*Pork and veggie dumplings (4/5)
Simple dumplings with juicy filling. Pretty basic so good to mix with the vinegar and ask for hot sauce if you like heat.

*Shanghai dumplings (3.5/5)
Technically prefer Dumpling Kitchen on Taraval better but I haven't had Shanghai dumpling king which is also on Balboa to compare. The skin is a bit thicker here than others but it's easy to eat and satisfies my craving. I appreciate the fact that the soup isn't boiling hot here too so you can eat it w/o scalding off all your tastebuds.

***Service***
Small place, one amazing woman servicing everyone. Order can take awhile to get them wings extra crispy but it's worth it! Also come early since there's normally a wait. Not good for big groups since the place is so small. 

***Location***
Parking is a bit rough since it's near the movie theater, purple kow and a ton of hot pot places and more restaurants. Just drop off a friend to put your name down since there can be a wait.

Whenever I'm craving wings we always go here. Pour that sauce over your rice, on your dumplings, shoootttt....I'd put that ish on everything!!

excerpts: We keep it simple and order the dry fried chicken wings and two orders of xiao long bao.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Heather O.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
My boyfriend and I absolutely love this place. He introduced me to this restaurant on my first visit to SF, and I can't get enough of this place! Our last trip to SF, we ate there twice within the 5 days we were there. We keep it simple and order the dry fried chicken wings and two orders of xiao long bao. That's it! 

Keep in mind, service is EXTREMELY slow. It seems like they pay more attention to take-out orders because they are always on the phone and working in the kitchen. They hardly ever come out to the dining room unless it is to bring an order to the table. So make sure you catch their attention when they are out in the dining room, because who knows when they will come back out from the kitchen. 

They also don't know when a customer comes in through the doors. There was a time my boyfriend and I were standing by the door waiting to be seated and it took a couple minutes for someone to come out and seat us. There was one instance where a couple was ready to order, but it took too long, they left. I only deduct one star for service, but their food is sooooo good, it really makes up for the terrible service.

excerpts:
We decided to order the Potstickers, Shanghai Dumplings, Dry Fried Chicken Wings, and Green Onion Pancake. 
All four of these dishes pertain to the basic dim sum meal, so we thought it would be a good idea to order these items. 
The potstickers weren't noticeably magnificent in taste, but they're still good!
The Shanghai Dumplings/Xiao Long Bao was great and definitely worth the order!
The chicken wings are probably close to San Tung quality and something worth checking out.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Jeffy Y.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
A great semi hole-in-the-wall dim sum place despite flaws in service!

1) First Impression
It was a Monday night around 7PM and there were many tables open. The lady quickly seated us and you can tell right away she's one of those grumpy old Chinese ladies. Nothing wrong with that though, but just saying. Also, this place is definitely quite small and I can imagine it being completely packed in here on perhaps a Friday night or weekend night.

2) Wait Time
My party of 3 did not have to wait on a Monday night around 7PM.

3) The Food
We decided to order the Potstickers, Shanghai Dumplings, Dry Fried Chicken Wings, and Green Onion Pancake. All four of these dishes pertain to the basic dim sum meal, so we thought it would be a good idea to order these items. 
The potstickers weren't noticeably magnificent in taste, but they're still good!
The Shanghai Dumplings/Xiao Long Bao was great and definitely worth the order!
The chicken wings are probably close to San Tung quality and something worth checking out.
The green onion pancake was also pretty crisp and is a great staple to have with the meal.

4) Service
The lady didn't smile a single time throughout the whole time we were there.
It seemed like she just wanted to get through the rest of the night and could care less about impeccable customer service. In addition, it took her about 20 minutes to give us our bill after we asked for it. However, this was OK because we were all having a nice conversation and wasn't in a rush to get out of the restaurant. To be honest, you shouldn't have high expectations on service if you're going to an authentic Chinese restaurant.

5) Pricing
The items are definitely leaning towards the pricey end of around $7-$11 per dish.
I don't know if the chicken wings are worth the ~$11 the menu advertises, but we were all full in the end and finished everything without any leftovers.

Keep in Mind: 
Parking may be harder to find, especially with Purple Kow across the street.
Speaking of Purple Kow, we went there right after dinner so it's a convenient location for some Dim Sum + Purple Kow combo.

*Final Verdict*
If you're looking for a good Dim Sum place and don't care too much about incredible customer service, then this is the place for you. I gave it 4 stars because the fair customer service really didn't bother me too much at that time.

excerpts: The Dry Fried Chicken Wings are the best in town!
They come out super hot and it is hard waiting for them to cool before eating them.
The Soup Dumplings are also great, add a Green Onion Pancake
and it is the perfect meal!
We have also enjoyed the Garlic Eggplant.
Expect a wait if you arrive during peak hours as it gets very busy!
This place is a ton better than the other place nearby that sells Soup Dumplings!
dry fried chicken wings.author: Michael B.
dry fried chicken wings.review: I love this place. Yes it is simple hallway of a space, and yes the owner/waitress can be a bit surly, but the food is out of sight and it is part of the charm right! The Dry Fried Chicken Wings are the best in town! They come out super hot and it is hard waiting for them to cool before eating them. The Soup Dumplings are also great, add a Green Onion Pancake and it is the perfect meal! We have also enjoyed the Garlic Eggplant. Expect a wait if you arrive during peak hours as it gets very busy! This place is a ton better than the other place nearby that sells Soup Dumplings!

excerpts: I recommend the dry fried chicken wings, Shanghai dumplings (duh), Shanghai style rice cakes, hand cut braised beef noodles, green onion pancake (the flakiest I've ever had), rice roll (only served in the morning), and pan fried dumplings.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Colleen L.
dry fried chicken wings.review: I'm a regular here and the cranky old Asian lady that everyone complains about is actually really nice.  What do you expect walking into a Chinese restaurant? Service is definitely not it... Anyways, if you're persistent enough to flag her down, then you will get to try some delicious Shanghainese food that you can't really get anywhere else in the city.  I recommend the dry fried chicken wings, Shanghai dumplings (duh), Shanghai style rice cakes, hand cut braised beef noodles, green onion pancake (the flakiest I've ever had), rice roll (only served in the morning), and pan fried dumplings.

excerpts: My friends and I came here to taste Shanghai House's dry fried chicken wings that has been said to be San Tung's respective rival.
Shanghai's wings have a more crunchy outer texture
but San Tung's wings still edge in flavor just a bit.
We also got their soup dumplings, eggplant with chicken & shrimp, spicy string beans, and noodles with meat sauce.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Kathy L.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
I would dine here for the food once a week if I didn't live so far from it! Cash only though and this place is small so expect a little wait depending on what time you arrive. I had to flag down the waitress a couple of times but what can you expect for a family ran Chinese restaurant.

My friends and I came here to taste Shanghai House's dry fried chicken wings that has been said to be San Tung's respective rival. Shanghai's wings have a more crunchy outer texture but San Tung's wings still edge in flavor just a bit. We also got their soup dumplings, eggplant with chicken & shrimp, spicy string beans, and noodles with meat sauce. I really liked each dish but they were definitely more on the thick saucy side (hello corn starch!).

All in all, good food and quite cheap when you eat it family style.

excerpts: We stopped here before heading to the Legion of Honor, and were pleasantly surprised by something called Dry Fried Chicken Wings.
dry fried chicken wings.author: Nadine S.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Tiny storefront in a residential area with amazing food!  We stopped here before heading to the Legion of Honor, and were pleasantly surprised by something called Dry Fried Chicken Wings.  We saw three other tables getting something that looked strangely unlike anything we had seen before, so we asked what it was and decided to try it.

We were so glad we did.  They were crispy, spicy,  savory, sweet and tangy - and delicious. 

We also had the House special noodle soup with hand cut noodles, and it was another great dish. The noodles had great texture, the broth was flavorful, and all the other stuff was perfectly cooked.

Service was OK, but the food made everything else worthwhile.

There were so many other things we wanted to try.   We would definitely recommend going out of your way to eat at this place!

excerpts: Came here after a fellow Yelper raved about their dry fried chicken wings.
They claimed it was better than San Tung
so we had to check it out.
We waited a little over 30 minutes for a table outside (no waiting area because the restaurant is so small).
They also don't have a waiting list
dry fried chicken wings.author: Kat C.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Came here after a fellow Yelper raved about their dry fried chicken wings. They claimed it was better than San Tung so we had to check it out. We waited a little over 30 minutes for a table outside (no waiting area because the restaurant is so small). They also don't have a waiting list so we just hoped the lady wouldn't forget about us.

The soup dumplings were the best thing we ordered. They definitely weren't the best I've ever had but we were uber hungry and ordered a second round.

As for the wings, they were crispy and tasty but I disagree that they are better than San Tung. It had a little kick to it but the sauce was off...think it was too sweet and not particularly memorable.
